editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

Late Lancashire witches
Witches of Lancashire.
Late Lancashire witches.
titleStmt.author: Heywood, Thomas, d. 1641.
Brome, Richard, d. 1652?.

div.p: A well received comedy, lately acted at the globe on the Bankside, by the King's majesty's actors.
Written, by Thom. Heywood, and Richard Broome.
London, printed by Thomas harper for Benjamin fisher, and are to be sold at his shop at the sign of the Talbot, without Aldersgate. 1634.

lg.l: Corantoes sailing, and no foot post late
Possessing us with new; of foreign state,
No accidents abroad worthy relation
Arriving here, we are forced from our own nation
To ground the scene that's now in agitation.
The project unto many here well known;
Those witches the fat jailor brought to town,
An argument so thin, persons so low
Can neither yield much matter, nor great show.
Expect no more than can from such be raised,
So may the scene pass pardoned, though not praised.

div.head: Actus, i. Scaena, i.
div.stage: Enter master Arthur, Mr. Shakstone, Mr. Bantam: (As from hunting.)

lg.l: Was ever sport of expectation,
Thus crossed in th' height.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Tush these are accidents, all game is (Subject to.

lg.l: So you may call them
Chances, or crosses, or what else you please,
But for my part, I'll hold them prodigies,
As things transcending nature.
O you speak this,
Because a hare hath crossed you.
A hare? A witch, or rather a devil I think .
For tell me gentlemen, was't possible
In such a fair course, and no covert near,
We in pursuit, and she in constant view,
Our eyes not wand'ring but all bent that way,
The dogs in chase, she ready to be ceased,
And at the instant, when I durst have laid
My life to gauge, my dog had pinched her, than
To vanish into nothing!

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Somewhat strange, but not as you enforce it,

lg.l: Make it plain
That I am in an error, sure I am
That I about me have no borrowed eyes.
They are mine own, and matches.
She might find some muse as then not visible to us,
And escape that way.
Perhaps some fox had earthed there,
and though it be not common, for I seldom
Have known or heard the like, there squat herself,
And so her scape appear but natural,
Which you proclaim a wonder.
Well well gentlemen, be you of your own faith, but (What I see
And is to me apparent, being in sense,
My wits about me, no way tossed nor troubled,
To that will I give credit.
Come, come, all men
Were never of one mind, nor I of yours.
To leave this argument, are you resolved
Where we shall dine today?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Yes where we purposed.

sp.speaker: Banth.
sp.p: That was with master generous.

lg.l: True, the same.
And where a loving welcome is presumed,
Whose liberal table's never unprepared,
Nor he of guests unfurnished, of his means,
There's none can bear it with a braver port,
And keep his state unshaken, one who sells not
Nor covets he to purchase, holds his own
Without oppressing others, always pressed
To endear to him any known gentleman
In whom he finds good parts.

sp.speaker: Bantham.
sp.p: A character not common in this age.

lg.l: I cannot wind him up
Unto the least part of his noble worth.
'Tis far above my strength.
See who comes yonder,
A fourth, to make us a full mess of guests
At master generous table.
Tush let him pass,
He is not worth our luring, a mere coxcomb,
It is a way to call our 〈◊〉 wits in question,
To have him seen amongst us.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: He hath spied us, there is no way to evade him.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: That's my grief; a most notorious liar, out upon him.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Let's set the best face on't.

lg.l: What gentlemen? all mine old acquaintance?
A whole triplicity of friends together? nay then
'Tis three to one we shall not soon part company.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Whetstone.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Dainty Mr. Whetstone.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Delicate master Whetstone.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: You say right, Mr. Whetstone I have been, Mr. Whetstone I am, and Mr. Whetstone I shall be, and those that know me, know withal that I have not my name for nothing, I am he whom all the brave blades of the country use to whet their wits upon; sweet Mr. Shakton, dainty Mr. Bantham, and dainty Mr. Arthur, and how, and how, what all lustick, all froligozone? I know, you are going to my uncle's to dinner, and so am I too, what shall we all make one rendezvous there,
You need not doubt of your welcome.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: No doubt at all kind Mr. Whetstone; but we have not seen you of late, you are grown a great stranger amongst us, I desire sometimes to give you a visit; I pray where do you lie?

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Where do I lie? why sometimes in one place, and then again in another, I love to shift lodgings; but most constantly, wheresoever I dine or sup, there do I lie?

lg.l: I never heard that word proceed from him
I durst call truth till now.
But wheresoever I lie 'tis no matter for that,
I pray you say, and say truth, are not you three now
Going to dinner to my uncle's?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: I think you are a witch master Whetstone.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: How? A witch gentlemen? I hope you do not mean to abuse me, though at this time (If report be true there are too many of them here in our country) but I am sure I look like no such ugly creature.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: It seems then you are of opinion that there are witches, for mine own part, I can hardly be induced to think there is any such kind of people.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: No such kind of people! I pray you tell me gentlemen, did never any one of you know my mother?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Why was your mother a witch?

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I do not say as witches go nowadays , for they for the most part are ugly old beldames, but she was a lusty young lass, and by her own report, by her beauty and fair looks bewitched my father.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: It seems then your mother was rather a young wanton wench, than an old withered witch.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: You say right, and know withal I come of two ancient families, for as I am a Whetstone by the mother-side, so I am a byblow by the fathers.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: It appears then by your discourse, that you came in at the window.

lg.l: I would have you think I scorn like my granam's
Cat to leap over the hatch.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: He hath confessed himself to be a bastard.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: And I believe't as a notorious truth.

lg.l: Howsoever I was begotten, here you see I am,
And if my parents went to it without fear or wit,
What can I help it.
Very probable, for as he was got without fear,
So it is apparent he was born without wit.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Gentlemen, it seems you have some private business amongst yourselves, which I am not willing to interrupt, I know not how the day goes with you, but for mine own part, my stomach is now much upon 12. You know what hour my uncle keeps, and I love ever to be set before the first grace, I am going before, speak, shall I acquaint him with your coming after?

sp.speaker: Shak
sp.p: We mean this day to see what fare he keeps.

lg.l: And you know it is his custom to fare well,
And in that respect I think I may be his kinsman,
And so farewell gentlemen, I'll be your forerunner,
To give him notice of your visit.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And so entire us to you.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Whetstone.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Kind Mr. By-blow.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p:
I see you are perfect both in my name and surname; I have 〈◊〉 ever bound unto you, for which I will at this time be your
noverint, and give him notice that you universi will be with him per praesentes, and that I take to be presently.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Farewell as in praesenti.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: It seems he's piece of a scholar.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What because he hath read a little scrivener's Latin, he never proceeded farther in his accidence than to mentiri non est meum; and that was such a hard lesson to learn, that he stuck at mentiri; and cued never reach to non est meum: since, a mere Ignaro, and not worth acknowledgement.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Are these then the best parts he can boast of?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: As you see him now, so shall you find him ever: all in one strain, there is one only thing which I wonder he left our.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: And what might that be:

lg.l: Of the same affinity with the rest.
At every second word, he his commonly boasting
Either of his aunt or his uncle.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: You name him in good time, see where he comes.

lg.l: Gentlemen, welcome, 'tis a word I use,
From me expect no further compliment:
Nor do I name it often at one meeting,
Once spoke (To those that understand me best,
And know I always purpose as I speak)
Hath ever yet sufficed: so jet it you;
Nor do I love that common phrase of guests,
As we make bold, or we are troublesome,
We take you unprovided, and the like;
I know you understanding gentlemen,
And knowing me, cannot persuade yourselves
With me you shall be troublesome or bold,
But still provided for my worthy friends,
Amongst whom you are lifted.
Noble sir, you generously instruct us, and to express
We can be your apt scholars: in a word
We come to dine with you.
And gentlemen, such plainness doth best please me, I had notice
Of so much by my kinsman, and to show
how lovingly I took it, instantly
Rose from my chair to meet you at the gate.
And be myself your usher; nor shall you find
Being set to meat, that I'll excuse your fare,
Or say, I am sorry it falls out so poor;
And had I known your coming we'd have had
Such things and such, nor blame my cook, to say
This dish or that hath not been sauced with care:
Words, fitting best a common hostess mouth,
When there's perhaps some just cause of dislike
But not the table of a gentleman;
Nor is it my wife's custom; in a word, take what you find, and so
Sir without flattery
You may be called the sole surviving son
Of long since banished hospitality.
In that you please me not: but gentlemen
I hope to be beholden unto you all,
Which if I prove, I'll be a grateful debtor.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Wherein good sir.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: I ever studied plainness, and truth withal.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: I pray express yourself.

lg.l: In few I shall. I know this youth to whom my wife is aunt
Is (As you needs must find him) weak and shallow:
Dull, as his name, and what for kindred's sake
We note not, or at least, are loath to see,
Is unto such well-knowing gentlemen
Most grossly visible: if for my sake
You will but seem to wink at these his wants,
At least at table before us his friends,
I shall receive it as a courtesy
Not soon to be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Presume it sir.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Now when you please pray enter gentlemen.

lg.l: Would these my friends prepare the way before,
To be resolved of one thing before dinner
Would something add unto mine appetite,
Shall I entreat you so much.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: O sir you may command us.

lg.l: I'th mean time
Prepare your stomachs with a bowl of sack.
My cellar can afford it; now Mr. Arthur
Pray freely speak your thoughts.
I come not sir
To press a promise from you, take't not so,
Rather to prompt your memory in a motion
Made to you not long since.
Wast not about
A manor, the best part of your estate,
Mortgaged to one slips no advantages
Which you would have redeemed.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: True sir the same.

lg.l: And as I think, I promised at that time
To become bound with you, or if the usurer
(A base, yet the best title I can give him)
Perhaps should question that security,
To have the money ready. Wast not so?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: It was to that purpose we discoursed.

lg.l: Provided, to have the writings in my custody.
Else how should I secure mine own estate.
To deny that I should appear toth' world
Stupid, and of no brain.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Your money's ready,

lg.l: And I remain a man obliged to you.
Beyond all utterance.
Make then your word good
By speaking it no further, only 〈◊〉 ▪
It seems your uncle you trusted in so far
Hath failed your expectation.
Sir he hath, not that he is unwilling or unable.
But at 〈◊〉 time unfit to be solicited;
For to the cowry's wonder and my sorrow,
He is much to be pitied.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Why I entreat you.

lg.l: Because he's late become the sole discourse
of all the country; for of a man respected
For his discretion and known gravity,
As master of a governed family,
The house (As if the ridge were fixed below,
And groundfils lifted up to make the roof)
All now turned topsy-turvy ,

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Strange, but how?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.l: In such a retrograde and preposterous way
As seldom hath been heard of. I think never.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Can you discourse the manner?

lg.l: The good man, in all obedience kneels unto his son,
He with an austere brow commands his father.
The wife presumes not in the daughter's sight
Without a prepared courtesy. The girl, she
Expects it as a duty; chides her mother
Who quakes and trembles at each word she speaks,
And what's as strange, the maid she domineers
O'er her young mistress, who is awed by her.
The son to whom the father creeps and bends,
Stands in as much fear of the groom his man.
All in such rare disorder, that in some
As it breeds pity, and in others wonder;
So in the most part laughter ▪

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: How think you might this come.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: 'Tis thought by witchcraft.

lg.l: They that think so dream,
For my belief is, no such thing can be,
A madness you may call it: dinner stays;
That done, the best part of the afternoon
We'll spend about your business.

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: Nay but understand me neighbour doughty.

sp.speaker: Doughty.
sp.p: Good master Seely I do understand you, and over and over understand you so much, that I could e'en blush at your fondness; and had I a son to serve me so, I would conjure a devil out of him.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: Alas he is my child.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: No, you are his child to live in fear of him, indeed they say old men become children again, but before I would become my child's child, and make my foot my head, I would stand upon my head, and kick my heels at the sides.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: You do not know what an only son is, oh see, he comes now if you can appease his anger towards me, you shall do an act of timely charity.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.l: It is an office that I am but weakly versed in,
To plead to a son in the father's behalf,
Bless me what looks the devilish young rascal

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I wonder at your confidence, and how you dare appear before me.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: A brave beginning.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: O son be patient.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: It is right reverend council, I thank you for it, I shall study patience shall I, while you practice ways to beggar me, shall I?

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Very handsome.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: If ever I transgress in the like again —

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I have taken your word too often sir and neither can nor will forbear you longer.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: What not your father Mr. Gregory?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: What's that to you sir?

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Pray tell me then sir, how many years has he to serve you.

lg.l: What do you bring your spokesman now, your advocate,
What fee goes out of my estate now, for his oratory?
Come I must tell you, you forget yourself,
And in this foul unnatural strife wherein
You trample on your father. You are fallen
Below humanity. You're so beneath
The title of a son, you cannot claim
To be a man, and let me tell you were you mine
Thou shouldst not eat but on thy knees before me.
O this is not the way.
This is to raise impatience into fury.
I do not seek his quiet for my ease,
I can bear all his chidings and his threats,
And take them well, very exceeding well,
And find they do me good on my own part,
Indeed they do reclaim me from those errors
That might impeach his fortunes, but I fear
Th'unquiet strife within him hurts himself,
And wastes or weakens nature, by the breach
Of moderate sleep and diet; and I can
No less than grieve to find my weaknesses
To be the cause of his affliction,
And see the danger of his health and being.
Alas poor man? Can you stand open eyed
Or dry eyed either at this now in a father?
Why, if it grieve you, you may look of on't,
I have seen more than this twice twenty times,
And have as often been deceived by his dissimulations
I can see nothing mended.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: He is a happy are that has brought up his son to this.

lg.l: All shall be mended son content yourself,
But this time forget but this last fault.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Yes, for a new one tomorrow.

lg.l: Pray Mr. Gregory forget it, you see how
Submissive your poor penitent is, forget it,
Forget it, put it out o'your head, knock it
Out of your brains. I protest, if my father,
Nay if my father's dog should have said
As much to me, I should have embraced him.
What was the trespass? It could not be so heinous.
Well sir, you now shall be a judge for all your jeering.
Was it a fatherly part think you having a son
To offer to enter in bonds for his nephew, so to endanger
My estate to redeem his mortgage.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: But I did it not son?

lg.l: I know it very well, but your dotage had done it,
If my care had not prevented it.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p:
Is that the business: why if he had done it, had he not
been sufficiently secured in having the mortgage made over to himself.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: He does nothing but practice ways to undo himself, and me: a very spendthrift, a prodigal sire, he was at the ale but tother day, and spent a fourpenny club.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: 'Tis gone and past son.

lg.l: Can you hold your peace sir? And not long ago at the
Wine he spent his taster, and two pence to the piper,
That was brave was it not?

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: Truly we were civilly merry. But I have left it.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Your civility have you not? For no longer ago than last holiday evening he gamed away eight double ringed tokens on a rubbers at bowls with the curate, and some of his idle companions.

lg.l: Fie Mr. Gregory Seely is this seemly in a son.
You'll have a rod for the child your father shortly I fear.
Alas did he make it cry? Give me a stroke and I'll beat him,
Bless me, they make me almost as mad as themselves.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: 'twere good you would meddle with your own matters sir.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: Son, son.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Sir, sir, as I am not beholden to you for house or land, for it has stood in the name of my ancestry the Seelyes above two hundred years, so will I look you leave all as you found it.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: What is the matter con you tell?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: O Lawrence, welcome, thou wilt make all well I am sure.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Yie whick way con you tell, but what the foul evil done ye, here's sick an a din.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Art thou his man fellow ha? that talkest thus to him?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Yie sir, and what my yoew o'that, he maintains me to rule him, and I'll do't, or ma'the heart weary o'the weambe on him.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: This is quite upside down, the son controls the father, and the man overcrows his master's coxcomb, sure they are all bewitched.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p:
'Twas but so, truly Lawrence; the peevish old man vexed me, for which I did my duty, in telling him his own, and
doughty here maintains him against me.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: I forbodden yeov to meddle with the old carl, and let me alone with him, yet you still be at him, he served you but we'll to baste ye for't, an't he were stronk enough, but an I favu foul with ye an I swaddle ye not savourly may my girts braced.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: Prithee good Lawrence be gentle and do not fright thy master so.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Yie, at your command anon.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Enough good Lawrence, you have said enough.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: How trow ye that? A fine world when a man cannot be whyet at home for busy brained neighbors.

lg.l: I know not what to say to any thing here,
This cannot be but witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I cannot endure it nor I will not endure it.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Hey day! the daughter upon the mother too.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: One of us two, choose you which, must leave the house, we are not to live together I see that, but I will know, if there be law in Lancashire for't, which is fit first to depart the house or the world, the mother or the daughter.

sp.speaker: Ioane.
sp.p: Daughter I say.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Do you say the daughter, for that word I say the mother, unless you can prove me the eldest, as my discretion almost warrant it, I say the mother shall out of the house or take such courses in it as shall sort with such a house and such a daughter.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: Daughter I say, I will take any course so thou wilt leave thy passion; indeed it hurts thee child, I'll sing and be merry, wear as fine clothes, and as delicate dressings as thou wilt have me, so thou wilt pacify thyself, and be at peace with me.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p:
O will yon so, in so doing I may chance to look upon you. Is this a fit habit for a handsome young gentlewoman's mother, as I hope to be a lady, you look like one o'the Scottish wayward sisters, oh my heart has got the hickup, and all
look 〈◊〉 green about 〈◊〉; a merry song now mother, and thou shalt be my white girl.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! she's overcome with joy at my conversion.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: She is most evidently bewitched.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: There was a deft lad and a lass fell in love,
With a fa la la, fa la la, langtidowne dilly;
With kissing and toying this maiden did prove,
With a fa la la, fa la la, langtidowne dilly;
So wide i'th waist, and her belly so high,
That unto her mother the maiden did cry,
Oh langtidowne dilly, oh langtidowne dilly,
Fa la la langtidowne, langtidowne dilly.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Thus wooden ye done and I were dead, but while I live yoeu fadge not on it, is this awe the work ye confine ?

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Now comes the maid to set her mistresses to work.

sp.speaker: Vvin.
sp.p: Nay prithee sweet Parnell, I was but chiding the old wife for her unhandsomeness, and would have been at my work presently, she tells me now she will wear fine things, and I shall dress her head as I list.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Here's a house well governed?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Dress me no dressings, lessen I dress ye beth, and learn a new lesson with a wainon right now, han I been a servant here this half dozen o'yeares, and con I fee ye idler than myself !

sp.speaker: Joa. Vvin.
sp.p: Nay prithee sweet Parnell content, and hark thee —

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: I have known this, and till very lately, as well governed a family as the country yields, and now what a nest of several humours it is grown, and all devilish ones, sure all the witches in the country, have their hands in this homespun medley; and there be no few 'tis thought.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p:
Yie, yeah, ye shall ye shall, another time, but not naw I thank ye, ye shall as soon piss and paddle in't, as slap me in the mouth with an awd petticoat, or a new pair 〈◊〉
shoine, to be whyet, I cannot be whyet, nor I wonot be whyet, to see sicky doings I.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Hold thy prattle Parnell, awes comed about as ween 'a had it, wotst thou what Parnell? wotst thou what? O dear, wotst thou what?

sp.speaker: P●rn.
sp.p: What's the fond wexen wailed trow I.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: We han been in love these three years, and ever we had not enough, now is it comed about that our love shall be at an end for ever, and a day, for we must wed may honey, we must wed.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: What the deowl ails the lymmer loon, been thy brains broke louse trow I.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Sick a waddin was there never i' Loncoshire as ween couple at on Monday newest.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Away awaw, sayen ye this sickerly, or done you but jaum me?

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: I jaum thee not nor flam thee not, 'tis all as true as book, here's both our masters have consented and concluded, and our mistresses must yield to it, to put awe house and land and awe they have into our hands.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Away, awaw.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: And we must marry and be master and dame of awe.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Away, awaw.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: And theyn be our sojourners, because they are weary of the world, to live in frendibleness, and see what will come on't.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Away, awaw, ago.

sp.speaker: Seel. and Greg.
sp.p: Nay 'tis true Parnell, here's both our hands on't, and give you joy.

sp.speaker: Joan. and Vvin.
sp.p: And ours too, and 'twill be fine ifackins.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Whaw, whaw, whaw, whaw!

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Here's a mad business towards.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: I will bespeak the guests.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: And I the meat:

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: I'll dress the dinner, though I drip my sweat.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: My care shall sumptuous parrelments provide.

sp.speaker: Vvin.
sp.p: And my best art shall trickly trim the bride.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Whaw, whaw, whaw, whaw.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I'll get choice music for the merriment.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: And I will wait with wonder the event.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Whaw, whaw, whaw, whaw.

div.head: Actus, ii. scaena, i.

lg.l: Hoe! well met, well met.
Meg. What new device, what dainty strain
More for our mirth now then our gain,
Shall we in practice put.
Nay dame,
Before we play another game.
We must a little laugh and thank
Our feat familiars for the prank
They played us last.
Or they will miss
Us in our next plot, if for this
They find not their reward.

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: 'Tis right.

lg.l: Therefore sing Maud, and call each spright.
Come away, and take thy duggy,

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: Come my Mamilion like a puggy,

lg.l: And come my puckling take thy teat,
Your travels have deserved your meat.
Now upon the churl's ground
On which we're met, let's dance a round;
That Cocle, Darnell, Poppia wild,
May choke his grain, and fill the field.
Now spirits fly about the task,
That we projected in our mask.
Now let us laugh to think upon
The feat which we have so lately done,
In the distraction we have set
In Seely's house; which shall beget
Wonder and sorrow amongst our foes,
whilst we make laughter of their woes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

lg.l: I can but laugh now to foresee,
The fruits of their perplexity.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Of Seely's family?

lg.l: Ay, ay, ay, the father to the son doth cry,
The son rebukes the father old;
The daughter at the mother scold,
The wife the husband check and chide,
But that's no wonder, through the wide
World 'tis common.
But to be short,
The wedding must bring on the sport
Betwixt the harebrained man and maid,
Master and dame that overswayed.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

lg.l: Enough, enough,
Our sides are charmed, or else this stuff
Would laughter-crack them; let's away
About the jig. we dance today,
To spoil the hunter's sport.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I that, be now the subject of our chat.

lg.l: Then list ye well, the hunters are
This day by vow to kill a hare,
Or else the sport they will forswear;
And hang their dogs up.
Stay, but where
Must the long threatned hare be found?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: They'll search in yonder meadow ground.

lg.l: There will I be, and like a wily Wat,
Until they put me up; I'll squat.
I and my puckling will a brace
Of greyhounds be, fit for the race;
And linger where we may be ta'en
Up for the course in the by-lane;
Then will we lead their dogs a course,
And every man and every horse;
Until they break their necks, and say —

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The devil on Dun is rid this way. Ha. ha, ha, ha.

lg.l: All the doubt can be but this,
That if by chance of me they miss,
And start another hare.
Then we'll not run
But find some way how to be gone.
I shall know thee Peg, by thy grizzled gut,
And I you Gilian by your gaunt thin gut.
But where will mawd bestow herself today?

sp.speaker: Mawd.
sp.p: On th' steeple top; I'll sit and see you play.

div.stage: Enter Mr. generous, Arthur, Bantam, Shakstone, and whetstone.

lg.l: At meeting, and at parting gentlemen,
I only make use of that general word,
So frequent at all feasts, and that but once; you're welcome.
You are so, all of you, and I entreat you
Take notice of that special business,
Betwixt this gentleman my friend, and I.
About the mortgage, to which writings drawn,
Your hands are witness.

sp.speaker: Baxt. and Shak.
sp.p: We acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: My hand is there too, for a man cannot set to his mark, but it may be called his hand; I am a gentleman both ways, and it hath been held that it is the part of a gentleman, to write a scurvy hand.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: You write sir like yourself.

lg.l: Pray take no notice of his ignorance,
You know what I foretold you.
'Tis confessed, but for that word by you so seldom spoke
By us so freely on your part performed,
We hold us much engaged.
I pray, no compliment,
It is a thing I do not use myself,
Nor do I love 't in others.
For my part, could I at once dissolve myself to words
And after turn them into matter; such
and of that strength, as to attract the attention
Of all the curious, and most itching ears
Of this our critic age; it could not make
A theme amounting to your noble worth:
You seem to me to super-arrogate,
Supplying the defects of all your kindred
To innoble your own name: I now have done sir.
Hey day, this gentleman speaks likes a country
Parson that had taken his text out of Ovid's metamorphosis.
Sir, you hyperbolize;
And I could chide you for't, but whilst you connive
At this my kinsman, I shall wink at you;
'Twil prove an equal match.
Your name proclaims
To be such as it speaks, you, generous.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Still in that strain!

lg.l: Sir, sir, whilst you persever to be good
I must continue grateful.
Gentlemen, the greatest part of this day you see is spent
In reading deeds, conveyances, and bonds,
With sealing and subscribing; will you now
Take part of a bad supper.
We are like travellers
And where such bait, they do not use to inn.
Our love and service to you.
The first I accept,
The last I entertain not, farewell gentlemen.
We'll try if we can find in our way home
When hares come from their coverts, to reliffe,
A course or too.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Say you so gentlemen, nay then I am for your company still, 'tis said hares are like hermaphrodites, one while male, and another female, and that which begets this year, brings young ones the next; which some think to be the reason that witches take their shapes so oft: nay if I lie Pliny lies too, but come, now I have light upon you, I cannot so lightly leave you farewell uncle.

lg.l: Cousin I wish you would consort yourself,
With such men ever, and make them your precedent,
For a more genteel carriage.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Good master generous —

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Robin.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Go call your mistress hither.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: My mistress sir, I do call her mistress, as I do call you master, but if you would have me call my mistress to my master, I may call loud enough before she can hear me.

lg.l: Why she's not deaf I hope, I am sure since dinner
She had her hearing perfect.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And so she may have at supper too for ought I know, but I can assure you she is not now within my call.

lg.l: Sirrah you trifle, give me the key oth' stable,
I will go see my gelding; i' th' mean time
Go seek her out, say she shall find me there.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: To tell you true sir, I shall neither find my mistress here, nor you your gelding there.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Ha! how comes that to pass?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Whilst you were busy about your writings, she came and commanded me to saddle your beast, and said she would ride abroad to take the air.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Which of your fellows did she take along to wait on her?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: None sir.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: None! hath she used it often?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Oftener I am sure then she goes to church, and leave out wednesdays and Fridayes.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: And still alone?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: If you call that alone, when nobody rides in her company.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: But what times hath she sorted for these journeys?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Commonly when you are abroad, and sometimes when you are full of business at home.

lg.l: To ride out often and alone, what say she
When she takes horse, and at her back return?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Only conjures me that I shall keep it from you, than claps me in the fist with some small piece of silver, and then a
fish cannot be more silent than I.

lg.l: I know her a good woman and well bred,
Of an unquestioned carriage, well reputed
Amongst her neighbours, reckoned with the best
And o'er me most indulgent; though in many
Such things might breed a doubt and jealousy,
Yet I hatch no such frenzy. Yet to prevent
The smallest jar that might betwixt us happen;
Give her no notice that I know thus much.
Besides I charge thee, when she craves him next
He be denied: if she be vexed or moved
Do not thou fear, I'll interpose myself
Betwixt thee and her anger, as you tender
Your duty and my service, see this done.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Now you have expressed your mind, I know what I have to do; first, not to tell her what I have told you and, next to keep her side-saddle from coming upon your gelding's back; but howsoever it is like to hinder me of many a round tester.

lg.l: As oft as thou deniest her, so oft claim
That taster from me, 't shall be roundly paid.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You say well in that sir, I dare take your word, you are an honest gentleman, and my master; and now take mine as I am your true servant, before she shall back your gelding again in your absence, while I have the charge of his keeping; she shall ride me, or I'll ride her.

lg.l: So much for that. Sirrah my butler tells me
My seller is drunk dry, I mean those bottles
Of sack and claret, are all empty grown
And I have guests tomorrow, my choice friends.
Take the grey nag i'th' stable, and those bottles
Fill at Lancaster,
There where you use to fetch it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Good news for me, I shall sir.

lg.l: O Robin, it comes short of that pure liquor
We drunk last term in London at the Myter
In Fleetstreet, thou remember'st it; methought
It was the very spirit of the grape,
mere quintessence of wine.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes sir, I so remember it, that most certain it is I never shall forget it, my mouth waters ever since when I but think on't, whilst you were at supper above, the drawer had me down into the cellar below, I know the way in again if I see't, but at that time to find the way out again, I had the help of more eyes than mine own: is the taste of that ipsitate still in your palate sir?

lg.l: What then? But vain are wishes, take those bottles
And see them filled where I command you sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I shall: never could I have met with such a fair opportunity: for just in the mid way lies my sweetheart, as lovely a lass as any is in Lancashire, and kisses as sweetly 〈◊〉 see her going or coming, I'll have one smouch at thy lips, and be with thee to bring mal Spencer.

lg.l: Go hasten your return, what he hath told me
Touching my wife is somewhat strange, no matter
Be't as it will, it shall not trouble me.
She hath not lyen so long so near my side,
That now I should be jealous.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: You seem sir a gentleman of quality, and no doubt but in your youth have been acquainted with affairs military, in your very looks there appears bounty, and in your person humanity. Please you to vouchsafe the tender of some small courtesy to help to bear a soldier into his country.

lg.l: Though I could tax you friend, and justly too
For begging 'gainst the statute in that name,
Yet I have ever been of that compassion,
Where I see want, rather to pity it
Than to use power. Where hast thou served?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: With the Russian against the Polack, a heavy war, and hath brought me to this hard fate. I was taken prisoner by the pole, and after some few weeks of durance, got both my freedom and pass. I have it about me to show, please you to vouchsafe the perusal.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: It shall not need. What countryman.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Yorkshire sir. Many a sharp battle by land, and many a sharp storm at sea, many a long mile, and many a short meal, I have travelled and suffered ere I could reach thus far, I 〈◊〉 you sir take my poor and wretched case into your worship's noble consideration.

lg.l: Perhaps thou lovest this wandring life
To be an idle loitering beggar, than
To eat of thine own labour.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Ay sir! Loitering I defy sir, I hate laziness as I do leprosy: it is the next way to breed the scurvy, put me to hedge, ditch, plow, thresh, dig, delve, any thing: your worship shall find that I love nothing less than loitering.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Friend thou speakest well.

div.stage: Enter miller (His ●andss and face scratched, and bloody.

sp.speaker: Miller.
sp.p: Your mill quoth he, if ever you take me in your mill again, I'll give you leave to cast my flesh to the dogs, and grind my flesh to powder, betwixt the millstones. Cat's do you call them, for their hugeness they might be cat a mountains, and for their claws, I think I have it here in red and white to show, I pray look here sir, a murrain take them, I'll be sworn they have 〈◊〉, where I am sure it itched not.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: How cam'st thou in this pickle?

sp.speaker: Ml.
sp.p: Yoiu see sir, and what you see, I have felt, and am come to give you to understand I'll not endure such another night if you would give me your mill for nothing, they say we Miller's are thieves: but I could as soon be hanged as steal one piece of a nap all the night long, good landlord provide yourself of a new tenant, the noise of such caterwauling, and such scratching and clawing, before I would endure again, I'll be tied to the sail when the wind blows sharpest, and they fly swiftest, till I be torn into as many fitters as I have toes and fingers.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: I was a miller myself before I was a soldier. What one of my own trade should be so poorly spirited frighted with cats?

lg.l: Sir trust me with the mill that he forsakes.
Here is a blade that hangs upon this belt
〈◊〉 spite of all these rats, cats, weasels, witches
or dogs, or devils, shall so conjure them
I'll quiet my possession.
Well spoken soldier.
I like thy resolution ▪ fellow, you then
Have given the mill quite over.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Over and over, here I utterly renounce it; nor would I stay in it longer, if you would give me your whole estate; nay if I say it, you may take my word landlord.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: I pray sir dare you trust your mill with me.

lg.l: I dare, but I am loath, my reasons these.
For many months, scarce any one hath lain there
But have been strangely frighted in his sleep,
Or from his warm bed drawn into the floor,
Or clawed and scratched, as thou seest this poor man,
So much, that it stood long untenanted,
Till he late undertook it, now thine eyes
Witness how he hath sped.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Give me the keys, I'll stand it all danger.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: 'Tis a match: deliver them.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Marry withal my heart, and I am glad, I am so rid of 'em.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Now I have gathered bullies, and filled my belly pretty well, I'll go see some sport. There are gentlemen coursing in the meadow hard by; and 'tis a game that I love better than going to school ten to one.
sp.stage: Enter an invisible spirit. I. Adson with a brace of greyhouds.
sp.p:
What have we here a brace of greyhounds broke loose from their masters: it must needs be so, for they have both their collars and slips about their necks. Now I look better upon them, methinks I should know them, and so I do: these are Mr. Robinson's dogs, that dwells some two miles off, I'll take them up, and lead them home to their master; it may be something in my way, for he is as liberal a gentleman, as any is in our country, come Hector, come. Now if I could but start a hare by the way, kill her, and carry her home to my supper, I should think I had
made a better afternoon's work of it than gathering of bullies. Come poor curs along with me.

div.stage: Enter Arthur, Bantam, Shakstone, and whetstone.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: My dog as yours.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A piece.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: I say the pied dog shall outstrip the brown.

sp.speaker: Whe.
sp.p: And I'll take the brown dogs part against the pied

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Yes when he's at his lap you'll take his part.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Bantam forbear him prithee.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: He talks so like an ass I have not patience to endure his non sense.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: The brown dog for two pieces.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Of what?

lg.l: Of what you dare; name them from the last
〈◊〉 with the double rings, to the late
Coy'nd 〈◊〉 which they say are all counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Well sir, I take 〈◊〉: will you cover these, give them into the hands of either of those two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: What needs that? do you think my word and my money is not all one?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And weigh alike: both many grains too light.
Enough of that, I presume Mr. Whetstone, you are not 〈◊〉 what belongs to the sport of hunting.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I think I have reason, for I have been at the death of more 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: More than you shed the last fall of the leaf.
More than any man here I am sure. I should be loath at these years to be ignorant of hairing or whoring. I know a hare close hunted, climb a tree.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: To find out birds 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Another 〈◊〉 into a river, nothing appearing above water, save only the tip of her nose to take breath.
Nay that's very likely, for no man can fish with an 〈◊〉 but his line must be made of hare.

lg.l: You say right, I know another, who to escape the
Dog's hath taken a house, and leapt in at a window.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: It is thought you came into the world that way.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: How mean you that?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Because you are a bastard.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Bastard! O base.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And thou art base all over.

lg.l: Needs must I now condemn your indiscretion,
To set your wit against his.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Bastard? that shall be tried; well gentlemen concerning hare-hunting you might have hard more, if he had had the grace to have said less, but for the word bastard, if I do not tell my uncle, I and my aunt too, either when I would speak ought or go of the score for any thing, let me never be trusted, they are older than I, and what know I, but they might be by when I was begotten; but if thou Bantam dost not hear of this with both thine ears, if thou hast them still, and not lost them by scribbling, instead of whetstone call me grindstone, and for byblow, Bulfinch. Gentlemen, for two of you your company is fair and honest; but for you Bantam, remember and take notice also, that I am a bastard, and so much I'll testify to my aunt and uncle.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What have you done, 'twill grieve the good old gentleman, to hear him baffled thus.

lg.l: I was in a cold sweat ready to faint
The time he stayed amongst us.

sp.speaker: Shak.

lg.l: But come, now the hare is found and started ▪
She shall have law, so to our sport.

sp.p:
A hare, a hare, hallo, halloe, the devil take these curs, will they not stir, halloe, halloe, there, there, there, what are they grown so lither and so lazy? Are Mr. 〈◊〉 dogs turned tykes with a wanion? the hare is yet in sight, halloe, halloe, marry hang you for a couple of 〈◊〉 (If you were worth hanging, and have you served me thus? 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 serve you with the like sauce, you shall to the next bush, there will I 〈◊〉 you, and use you like a couple of curs as you are, and though not lash you, yet
lash you whilst my switch will hold, nay since you have left your speed, I'll see if I can put spirit into you, and put you in remembrance what halloe, halloe means.
sp.stage: As he beats them, there appears before him, goody Dickison, and the boy upon the dogs, going in.
sp.p: Now bless me heaven, one of the greyhounds turned into a woman, the other into a boy! The lad I never saw before, but her I know well; it is my gammer Dickison.

lg.l: Sirrah, you have served me well to swinge me thus.
You young rogue, you have used me like a dog.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: When you had put yourself into a dog's skin, I pray how could I help it; but gammer are not you a witch? if you be, I beg upon my knees you will not hurt me.

lg.l: Stand up my boy, for thou shalt have no harm,
Be silent, speak of nothing thou hast seen.
And here's a shilling for thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I'll have none of your money gammer, because you are a witch: and now she is out of her four legged shape, I'll see if with my two legs I can outrun her.

sp.speaker: Dickis.
sp.p: Nay sirrah, though you be young, and I old, you are not so nimble, nor I so lame, but I can overtake you.

lg.l: But gammer what do you mean to do with me
Now you have me?
To hug thee, stroke thee, and embrace thee thus,
And teach thee twenty thousand pretty things.
So thou tell no tales; and boy this night
Thou must along with me to a brave feast.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Not I gammer indeed-la la, I dare not stay on't late, my father is a fell man, and if I be out long, will both chide and beat me.

lg.l: Not sirrah, then perforce thou shalt along,
This bridle helps me still at need,
And shall provide us of a steed.
Now sirrah, take your shape and be
Prepared to hurry him and me.
Now look and tell me where's the lad become.
The boy is vanished, and I can see nothing in his stead
but a white horse ready saddled and bridled.

sp.speaker: Dickis.

lg.l: And that's the horse we must bestride,
On which both thou and I must ride,
Thou boy before and I behind,
The earth we tread not, but the wind,
For we must progress through the air,
And I will bring thee to such fare
As thou never sawest, up and away,
For now no longer we can stay.

sp.stage: She catches him up, and turning round ▪ 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Help, help.
Thanks my sweet mall for thy courteous entertainment, thy cream, thy cheesecakes, and every good thing, this, this, and this for all.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But why in such haste good Robin?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I confess my stay with thee is sweet to me, but I must spur cut the faster for't, to be at home in the morning, I have yet to Lancaster to ride tonight , and this my 〈◊〉 of bottles, to fill tonight , and then half a score mile to ride by currycomb time, i'the morning, or the old man chides mal.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: He shall not chide thee, fear it not.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Pray Bacchus I may please him with his wine, which will be the hardest thing to do; for since he was last at London and tasted the divinity of the ▪ mitre, scarce any liquor in Lancashire will go down with him, sure, sure he will never be a Puritan, he holds so well with the mitre.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well Robert, I find your love by your haste from me, I'll undertake you shall be at Lancaster, and twice as far, and yet at home time enough, and be ruled by me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Thou art a witty rogue, and thinkst to make me believe any thing, because I saw thee make thy broom sweep the house without hands tother day.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You shall see more than that presently, because you shall believe me; you know the house is all a-bed here: and I dare not be missed in the morning. Besides, I must be at the wedding of Lawrence and Parnell tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I your old sweet heart Lawrence? Old love will not be forgotten

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I care not for the loss of him, but if I 〈◊〉 him not hang me: but to the point, if I go with you tonight , and help you to as good wine as your master desires, and you keep your time with him, you will give me a pint for my company.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Thy belly full wench.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I'll but take up my milk pail and leave it in the field, till our coming back in the morning, and we'll away.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Go fetch it quickly then.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: No Robert, rather than leave your company so long, it shall come to me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I would but see that.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Look yonder, what do you think on't.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Light, it comes; and I do think there is so much of the devil in't as will turn all the milk shall come in't these seven years, and make it burn too, till it stink worse than the proverb of the Bishop's foot.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Look you sir, here I have it, will you get up and away.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: My horse is gone, nay prithee mal. thou hast set him away, leave thy roguery.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Look again.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: There stands a black long-sided jade: mine was a trussed grey.

lg.l: Yours was too short to carry double such a journey.
Get up I say, you shall have your own again i'th morning.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Nay but, nay but.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay, and you stand butting now, I'll leave you to look your horse. Pail on afore to the field, and stay till I come.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Come away then, heigh for Lancaster: stand up ▪

div.head: Actus, iii. Scaena, i.
div.stage: Enter old Seely and Ióane his wife.

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: Come away wife, come away, and let us be ready to break the 〈◊〉 over the bride's head at her entrance; we will have the honour of it, we that have played the steward and cook at home, though we lost church by't, and saw not parson knit-knot do his office, but we shall see all the house rites performed; and. 〈◊〉 what a day of jollity and tranquillity is here towards?

sp.speaker: Ioane ▪
sp.p: You are so frolic and so crank now, upon the truce is taken amongst us, because our wrangling shall not wrong the wedding, but take heed (You were best) how ye behave yourself, lest a day to come may pay for all.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: I fear nothing, and I hope to die in this humour.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: O how hot am I ● rather than I would dress such another dinner this twelvemonth , I would wish wedding quite out of this years almanac ▪

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: I'll fetch a cup of sack wife —

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: How brag he is of his liberty, but the holy day carries it.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: Here, here sweetheart, they are lóng methinks a coming, the bells have rung out this half hour, hark now the wind brings the sound of them sweetly again.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: They ring backwards methinks .

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: I fack they do, sure the greatest fire in the parish is in our kitchen, and there's no harm done yet, no 〈◊〉 some merry conceit of the stretch ▪ ropes the ringers, now they have done, and now the wedding comes, hark, the fiddlers and all, now have I lived to see a day ▪ come, take 〈◊〉 stand, and be ready for the bridecake, which we will so crack and crumble upon her crown: oh they come, they come.

div.stage: Enter musicians, Lawrence, Parnell, Win. Mal. Spencer, two country lasses Doughty, greg. Arthur, Shakton, Bant 〈◊〉 and Whetstone.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Joy, health; and children to the married pair.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: And Parn. We thank you all.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: So pray come in and fare.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: As well as we and taste of every cate:

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: With bonny bridegroom and his love mate.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: This begins bravely.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: They agree better than the bells e'en now, 'slid they sang tunably till we were all out of the church, and then they clattered as the devil had been in the belfry: on in the name of wedlock, fiddlers on.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: On with your melody.

lg.l: Enter the gates with joy,
And as you enter play the sack of Troy.

div.stage: The fiddlers pass through, and play the battle.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: Welcome bride Parnell.

sp.speaker: Seel.

lg.l: Bridegroom 〈◊〉 〈◊〉,
In you before, for we this cake must break.
Over the bride —
Forgive me - what's become
Of th' cake wife!

sp.stage: As they l●fted up the cake, the spirit snatches it, and powers down 〈◊〉.

sp.p: It 〈◊〉 out of my hand, and is 〈◊〉 into 〈◊〉 I think.

sp.speaker: Dough●.
sp.p: 〈◊〉? the devil of crumb is here, but bran; nothing but bran, what prodigy 〈◊〉 this?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Is my best brides cake come to this! Oh uvea warth it.
How daintily the bride's hair is powdered with it.
My 〈◊〉 stands 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 to see it.
And mine.
I was never so amazed!

sp.speaker: Dougb.
sp.p: What 〈◊〉 mean?
Pax, I think 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 but some of my father and mother's roguery, this is a law-day with 'em, to 〈◊〉 what they list.
I never fear any thing, so long as my 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 but bidden me think of her, and 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 me.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Well gentlemen, let's follow the 〈◊〉 in, and fear nothing yet, the house smells well of good 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: Gentlemen, will it please you draw near, the guests are now all come, and the house almost full, meat's taken up.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: We were now coming.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: But son Gregory, nephew Arthur, and the rest of the young gentlemen, I shall take it for a favour if you will (It is an office which very good gentlemen do in this country) accompany the bridegroom in serving the meat.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: Nay neighbour doughty, your years shall excuse you.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Peugh, I am not so old but I can carry more meat than I can eat, if the young 〈◊〉 could carry their drink as well, the country would be quieter —

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: Well fare your hearts, — the dresser calls in gentlemen,

'Tis a busy time, yet will I review the bill of fare, for this day's dinner — (Reads) for 40 ▪ people of the best quality, 4. messes of meat; viz. a leg of mutton in plum-broth, a dish of marrowbones, a 〈◊〉 white-broth, a sirloin of beef, a big, a goose, a Turkey, and two pies: for the second course, to every mess 4. Chickens in a dish, a couple of rabbits, custard, flawn, Florentines, and stewed prunes, — all very good country fare, and for my credit, —
sp.stage: Enter 〈◊〉 playing before, Lawrence, Doughty, Arthur, 〈◊〉 Bantam, Whetstone, and Gregory, with dishes: a spirit (Over the door) does some action to the dishes as they enter.
sp.p: The service enters, oh well said 〈◊〉, play up the meat to the table till all be served in, I'll see it pass in answer to my bill.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Hold up your head Mr. bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: On afore fiddlers, my 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 in my honds.

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: Inprime, a leg of mutton in plum-broth, — how now Mr. bridegroom, what carry you?

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: 'Twere hot even now, but now it's cawed as a stone.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: A stone, 'tis horn man.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Awe —

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: It was mutton, but now 'tis the horns 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Awe where's my bride —

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: 'zookes, I brought as good a sirloin of beef from the dresser as knife could be put to, and see — I'll stay i' this house no longer.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: And if this were not a capon in white broth, I am one i' the coop.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: All, all's transformed, look you what I have!

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: And i! Yet I fear nothing thank my aunt.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I had a pie that is not opened yet, I'll see what's in that — live birds as true as I live, look where they fly!

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Witches, live witches, the house is full of witches, if we love our lives let's out on't.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: O husband, oh guests, oh son, oh gentlemen, such a chance in a kitchen was never heard of, all the meat is flown out of the chimney top I think, and nothing instead of it, but snakes, bats, frogs, beetles, hornets, and humble-bees; all the salads are turned to jews-ears, mushrooms, and puck fists; and all the custards into cow shards!

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: What shall we do, dare we stay any longer?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Dare we! why not, I defy all witches, and all their works; their power on our meat, cannot reach our persons.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I say so too, and so my aunt ever told me, so long I will fear nothing; be not afraid Mr. doughty.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Zooks, I fear nothing living that I can see more than you, and that's nothing at all, but to think of these invisible mischiefs, troubles me I confess.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p:
Sir I will not go about to overrule your reason, but
but for my part I will not out of a house on a bridal day, till I see the last man born.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Zooks thou art so brave a fellow that I will stick to thee, and if we come off handsomely, I am an old bachelor thou knowest, and must have an heir, I like thy spirit, where's the bride? where's the bridegroom? where's the music? where be the lasses? ha' you any wine i' the house, though we make no dinner ▪ let's try if we can make an afternoon.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: Nay sir if you please to stay, now that the many are frighted away, I have some good cold meats, and half a dozen bottles of wine.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: And I will bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Say you me so, but will not your son be angry, and your daughter chide you.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Fear not you that sir, for look you I obey my father.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: And I my mother.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: And we are all at this instant as well and as sensible of our former errors, as you can wish us to be.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Nam, if the witches have but robbed of your meat, and restored your reason, here has been no hurt done today, but this is strange, and as great a wonder as the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: It seems though these hags had power to make the wedding cheer a deceptio visus, the former store has scaped 'em.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: I am glad on't, but the devil good 'em with my sirloin, I thought to have set that by mine own trencher — but you have cold meat you say?

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: And wine you say?

sp.speaker: Ioane.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: I hope the country wenches and the fiddlers are not gone.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: They are all here, and one the merriest wench; that makes all the rest so laugh and tickle.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: Gentlemen will you in?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed on all parts.

sp.speaker: Dought,
sp.p: If not a wedding we will make a wake on't, and away with the witch; I fear nothing now you have your wits again: but look you, hold 'em while you have 'em.

div.stage: Enter generous, and Robin, with a paper.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: I confess thou hast done a wonder in fetching me so good wine, but my good servant Robert, go not about to put a miracle upon me, I will rather believe that Lancaster affords this wine, which I thought impossible till I tasted it, then that thou couldst in one night fetch it from London.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I have known when you have held me for an honest fellow, and would have believed me.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Th' art a knave to wish me to believe this, forgi'me, I would have sworn if thou hadst stayed but time answerable for the journey (To his that flew to Paris and back to London in a day) it had been the same wine, but it can never fall within the compass of a Christian's belief, that thou couldst ride above three hundred miles in 8. hours: you were no longer out, and upon one horse too, and in the night too!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And carry a wench behind me too, and did something else too, but I must not speak of her lest I be devil-torn.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: And fill thy bottles too, and come home half drunk too, for so thou art, thou wouldst never a had such a fancy else!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I am sorry I have said so much, and not let Lancaster have the credit of the wine.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: O are you so! and why have you abused me and yourself then all this while, to glorify the Myter in Fleetstreet?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I could say sir, that you might have the better opinion of the wine, for there are a great many palates in the kingdom that can relish no wine, unless 〈◊〉 be of such a tavern, and drawn by such a drawer —

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I said, and I say again, if I were within ten mile of London, I durst swear that this was mitre wine, and drawn by honest Jack pain.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Nay then sir I swore, and I swear again, honest Jack pain drew it.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, if I could believe there were such a thing as witchcraft, I should think this slave were bewitched now with an opinion.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Much good do you sir, your wine and your mirth, and my place for your next groom, I desire not to stay to be laughed out of my opinion.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Nay be not angry robin, we must not part so, and how does my honest drawer? ha, ha, ha; and what news at London, Robin? ha, ha, ha; but your stay was so short I think you could hear none, and such your haste home that you could make none: is't not so robin? ha, ha, ha, what a strange fancy has good wine begotten in his head?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Now will I push him over and over with a piece of paper: yes sir, I have brought you something from London.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Come on, now let me hear.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Your honest drawer sir, considering that you considered him well for his good wine —

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What shall we hear now?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Was very careful to keep or convey this paper to you, which it seems you dropped in the room there.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Bless me! this paper belongs to me indeed, 'tis an acquittance, and all I have to show for the payment of one hundred pound, I took great care for't, and could not imagine where or how I might lose it, but why may not this be a trick? this knave may find it when I lost it, and conceal it till now to come over me withal. I will not trouble my thoughts with it further at this time, well Robin look to your business, and have a care of my gelding.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Yes sir. I think I have nettled him now, but not as I was nettled last night, three hundred miles a night upon a rawboned devil, as in my heart it was a devil, and then a wench that shared more of my back then the said devil did of my bum, this is rank riding my masters: but why had I such an itch to tell my master of it, and that he should believe it; I do now wish that I had not told, and that he will not believe it, for I dare not tell him the means: 'sfoot my wench and her friends the fiends, will tear me to pieces if I discover her; a notable rogue, she's at the wedding now, for as good a maid as the best of 'em — oh my mistress.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. generous, with a bridle.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Robin.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I mistress.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Quickly good robin, the grey gelding.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: What other horse you please mistress.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: And why not that?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Truly mistress pray pardon me, I must be plain with you, I dare not deliver him you; my master has ta'en notice of the ill case you have brought him home in divers times.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: O is it so, and must he be made acquainted with my actions by you, and must I then be controlled by him, and now by you; you are a saucy groom.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You may say your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: No sir, I'll do my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Awe.

lg.l: Horse, horse, see thou be,
And where I point thee carry me.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Was there ever such a medley of mirth, madness, and drunkenness, shuffled together.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Thy uncle and aunt, old Mr. silly and his wife, do nothing but kiss and play together like monkeys.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Yes, they do overlove one another now.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And young Gregory and his sister do as much overdo their obedience now to their parents.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: And their parents as much overdote upon them, they are all as far beyond their wits now in loving one another, as they were wide of them before in crossing.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Yet this is the better madness.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: But the married couple that are both so daintily whittled, that now they are both mad to be a-bed before suppertime, and by and by he will, and she wo' not; straight she will and he wo' not, the next minute they both forget they are married, and defy one another.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: My sides e'en ache with laughter.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p:
But the best sport of all is, the old bachelor master
doughty, that was so cautious, and feared every thing to be witchcraft, is now wound up to such a confidence that there is no such thing, that he dares the devil do his worst, and will not out o'the house by all persuasion, and all for the love of the husbandman's daughter within, mal Spencer.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: There I am in some danger, he put me into half a belief I shall be his heir, pray love she be not a witch to charm his love from me. Of what condition is that wench dost thou know her?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: A little, but Whetstone knows her better.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Hang him rogue, he'll belie her, and speak better than she deserves, for he's in love with her too. I saw old Doughty give him a box o'the ear for kissing her, and he turned about as he did by thee yesterday, and swore his aunt should know it.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Who would ha'thought that impudent rogue would have come among us after such a baffle.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: He told me, he had complained to his aunt on us, and that she would speak with us.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: We will all to her to patch up the business, for the respect I bear her husband, noble generous.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Here he comes.

lg.l: Hark you Mr. By-blow do you know the lass within?
What do you call her, mal Spencer?

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Sir, what I know I'll keep to myself, a good civil merry harmless rogue she is, and comes to my aunt often, and that's all I know by her.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: You do well to keep it to yourself sir.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: And you may do well to question her if you dare. For the testy old coxcomb that will not let her go out of his hand.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Take heed, he's at your heels.

div.stage: Enter Doughty, ma●, two country lasses

lg.l: Come away wenches, where are you gentlemen?
Play fiddlers: let's have a dance ▪ ha my little rogue.
Zooks what ails thy nose.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: My nose! Nothing sir. —Turns about— Yet methought a fly touched it. Did you see any thing?

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: No, no, yet I would almost ha' sworn, I would not have sprite or goblin blast thy face, for all their kingdom. But hang't there is no such thing: fiddlers will you play?
Gentlemen will you dance?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.l: This family of love? Let's have them into the revels.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Hold a little then.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: O father twenty times a day is too little to ask you blessing.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: Go too you are a rascal: and you housewife teach your daughter better manners: I'll ship you all for new England else.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: The knot's untied, and this is another change.

sp.speaker: Ioane.
sp.p: Yes I will teach her manners, or put her out to spin two penny tow: so you dear husband will but take me into favour: I'll talk with you dame when the strangers are gone.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Dear father.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Dear mother.

sp.speaker: Greg. Win.
sp.p: Dear father and mother pardon us but this time.

sp.speaker: See. Joa.
sp.p: Never, and therefore hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Nay that's unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Greg. Vvin.
sp.p: Oh! —Weep.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: But for your sake I'll forbear them, and bear with any thing this day.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Do you note this? Now they are all worse than ever they were, in a contrary vain: what think you of witchcraft now?

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: They are all natural fool's man, I find it now.
Art thou mad to dream of witchcraft?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: He's as much changed and bewitched as they I fear.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Hey day! Here comes the pair of boiled lovers in Sorrell sops.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Nay dear honey, nay honey, but eance, eance.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Nam, na, I have swarm, I have swarm, not a bit afore bed, and look ye it's but now dancing time.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Come away bridegroom, we'll stay your stomach with a dance. Now masters play a good: come my lass we'll show them how 'tis

div.stage: As they begin to dance, they play another tune, then fall into many.

sp.speaker: Ar. Ban. Sha.
sp.p: Whether now, ho?

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Hey day! why you rogues.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: What does the devil ride of your fiddlestickes.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: You drunken rogues, hold, hold, I say, and begin again soberly the beginning of the world

div.stage: Music. Every one a several tune.

sp.speaker: Arth. Bant. Shak
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, how's this?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Every one a several tune

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: This is something towards it. I bade them play the beginning of the world, and they play, I know not what.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: No 'tis running of the country several ways.
But what do you think on't.

sp.speaker: Dough
sp.p: Think! I think they are drunk prithee do not thou think of witchcraft; for my part, I shall as soon think this maid one, as that there's any in Lancashire.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ha, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Why dost thou laugh?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: To think this bridegroom should once ha' been mine, but he shall rue it, I'll hold him this point on't, and that's all I care for him.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: A witty rogue.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I tell you sir, they say she made a pail follow her tother day up two pair of stairs.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: You lying rascal.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: O sir forget your anger.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Look you Mr. bridegroom, what my care provides for you

sp.speaker: Lawrence.
sp.p: What, a point?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yes put it in your pocket it may stand you instead anon, when all your points be ta'en away, to truss up your trinkets, I mean your slopes withal.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Mal for awed acquaintance I will ma' thy point a point of preferment. It shan be the foreman of a haell Jewry o'points, and right here will I wear it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Wy'a, wy'a, awed leove woe no be forgotten, but ay's never be jealous the mare for that.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Play fiddlers any thing.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Ay, and let's see your faces, that you play fairly with us.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: We do sir, as loud as we can possibly.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Play out that we may hear you.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: So we do sir, as loud as we can possibly.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Do you hear any thing?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Nothing not we sir.

lg.l: 'Tis so, the rogues are bribed to cross me,
And their fiddles shall suffer, I will break 'em as small as the
Bride cake was today.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Look you sir, they'll save you a labour, they are doing it themselves.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: O brave fiddlers, there was never better scuffling for the Tudberry bull.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: This is mother Johnson and Gooddy Dickison's roguery, I find it but I cannot help it, yet I will have music: sir there's a piper without, would be glad to earn money.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: She has spoke to purpose, and whether this were witchcraft or not: I have heard my aunt say twenty times, that no witchcraft can take hold of a Lancashire bagpipe, for itself is able to charm the devil, I'll fetch him.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p:
Well said, a good boy nów; come bride and bridegroom, leave your kissing and fooling, and prepare to come into the dance. We'll have a hornpipe, and then a posset and
to bed when you please. Welcome piper, blow till thy bag crack again, a lusty hornpipe, and all into the dance, nay young and old.

div.stage: Dance. Lawrence and Parnell reel in the dance. At the end, Mal vanishes, and the piper.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Bravely performed.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Stay, where's my lass?

sp.speaker: Arth. Ban. Shak
sp.p: Vanished, she and the piper both vanished, nobody knows how.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Now do I plainly perceive again, here has been nothing but witchery all this day; therefore into your posset, and agree among yourselves as you can, I'll out o'the house. And gentlemen, if you love me or yourselves, follow me.

sp.speaker: Ar. Bant. Sha. Whet.
sp.p: Ay, ay, away, away.

sp.speaker: See.
sp.p: Now good son, wife, and daughter, let me entreat you be not angry.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: O you are a trim mother are you not?

sp.speaker: Joa.
sp.p: Indeed child, I'll do so no more.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Now sir, I'll talk with you, your champions are all gone.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: We'll sir, and what won ye deow than?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Whay, whay, what's here to do? Come awaw, and whickly, and see us into our brayd chember, and delicately lodged together, or we'll whap you out o'dores ith' morn to sojourn in the common, come away.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We follow ye.

div.head: Actus, iv. Scaena, i.
div.p: Know you this gingling bridle, if you see't again? I wanted but a pair of gingling spurs to make you mend your pace, and put you into a sweat.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p:
Yes, I have reason to know it after my
hard journey, they say there be light women, but for your own part, though you be merry. Yet I may be sorry for your heaviness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gener.
sp.p: I see thou art not quite tired by shaking of thyself, 'tis a sign that as thou hast brought me hither, so thou art able to bear me back, and so you are like good Robert. You will not let me have your master's gelding, you will not. Well fir, as you like this journey, so deny him to me hereafter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You say well mistress, you have jaded me (A pox take you for a jade.) Now I bethink myself how damnably did I ride last night, and how devilishly have I been rid now.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Do you grumble you groom? Now the bridle's of, I turn thee to grazing gramercy my good horse, I have no better provender for thee at this time, thou hadst best like Aesop's ass to feed upon thistles, of which this place will afford thee plenty. I am bid to a better banquet, which done, I'll take thee up from grass, spur cut, and take a short cut home. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: A pox upon your tail.

div.stage: Enter all the witches and Mal, at several doors.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The lady of the feast is come, welcome, welcome.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Is all the cheer that was prepared to grace the wedding feast, yet come?

lg.l: Part of it's here.
The other we must pull for. But what's he?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: My horse, my horse, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
My horse, my horse, I would I were now some country major, and in authority, to see if I would not venture to rouse your satanical sisterhood: horse, horse, see thou be, and where I point thee, carry me: is that the trick on't? the devil himself shall be her carrier next if I can shun her: and yet my Mr. will not believe there's any witches: there's no running away; for I neither know how nor whither, besides to my thinking, there's a deep ditch, and a high quickset about me, how shall I pass the time? What place is this? it looks like an old barn: I'll peep in at some cranny or other, and try if I can see what they are doing. Such a bevy of beldames did I never behold; and 〈◊〉.
like so many cormorants: marry choke you with a mischief.

sp.speaker: Gooddy Dickison.
sp.p: Whoop, whir, here's a stir, never a cat, never a cur, but that we must have this demur.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A second course.

lg.l: Pull, and pull hard
For all that hath lately been prepared
For the great wedding feast.
As chief.
Of doughtyes surloin of roast beef.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: 'Tis come, 'tis come.

sp.speaker: Mawd.
sp.p: Where hath it all this while been?

lg.l: Some
Delay hath kept it, now 'tis here,
For bottles next of wine and beer,
The merchant's cellars they shall pay for't.
Well,
What sod or roast meat more, pray tell.
Pull for the poultry, foul, and fish,
For empty shall not be a dish.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: A pox take them, must only they feed upon hot meat, and I upon nothing but cold salads

lg.l: This meat is tedious, now some fairy,
Fetch what belongs unto the dairy.
That's butter, milk, whey, curds and cheese,
We nothing by the bargain lose.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Goody Dickison.
sp.p: Boy, there's meat for you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Gooddy Dickis
sp.p: And drink too.

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: What beast was by thee hither rid?

sp.speaker: Mawd.
sp.p: A badger nab.

lg.l: And I bestrid
A porcupine that never pricked.
The dull sides of a bear I kicked.
I know how you rid lady Nan,

sp.speaker: Mrs. gen,
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, upon the knave my man.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: A murrain take you, I am sure my hooves paid for't.
