sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Meat lie there, for thou hast no taste, and drink there, for thou hast no relish, for in neither of them is there either salt or savour.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Pull for the posset, pull.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: The bride's posset on my life, nay if they come to their spoon meat once, I hope they'll break up their feast presently.

lg.l: So those that are our waiters near,
Take hence this wedding cheer.
We will be lively all, and make this barn our hall.
You our familiars, come.
In speech let all be dumb,
And to close up our feast,
To welcome every gest
A merry round let's dance.
Some music then 〈◊〉 air
Whilst thus by pair and pair,
We nimbly foot it; strike.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: We are obeyed.

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.p: And we hell's ministers shall lend our aid.

div.stage: Dance and song together. In the time of which the boy speaks.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Now whilst they are in their jollity, and do not mind me, I'll steal away, and shift for myself, though I lose my life for't.

lg.l: Enough, enough, now part,
To see the brides vexed heart,
The bridegrooms too and all,
That vomit up their gall
For lack o'th wedding cheer.

sp.speaker: Gooddy Dickison.
sp.p: But stay, where's the boy, look out, if he escape us, we are all betrayed.

lg.l: No following further, yonder horsemen come,
In vain is our pursuit, let's break up court.

sp.speaker: Gooddy Dickison.
sp.p: Where shall we next met?

sp.speaker: Mawd.
sp.p: At Mil● ▪

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: But when ▪

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: At night.

lg.l: To horse, to horse.
2. Where's my Mamilian.
1. And my Mamilian.
3. My tiger to bestride.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: My puggy.

lg.l: My horse.
The night we have feasted, now comes on the day.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Away, away,

lg.l: Come sirrah, stoop your head like a tame jade,
Whilst I put on your bridle.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I pray mistress ride me as you would be rid.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: That's at full speed,

sp.speaker: Rob.

lg.l: Nay then I'll try conclusions.
Mare mare, see thou be,
And where I point thee carry me.

sp.stage: A great noise within at their parting. Exeunt.

lg.l: I see what man is loath to entertain,
Offers itself to him most frequently,
And that which we most covet to embrace,
Doth seldom court us, and proves most averse;
For I, that never could conceive a thought
Of this my woman worthy a rebuke,
(As one that in her youth bore her so fairly
That she was taken for a seeming saint)
To render me such just occasion,
That I should now distrust her in her age;
Distrust! I cannot, that would bring me in
The poor aspersion of fond jealousy;
Which even from our first meeting I abhorred.
The gentile fashion so 〈◊〉 we observe
To sunder beds; but most in these hot months
June, July August, so we did last night.
Now I (As ever tender of her health)
And therefore rising early as I use,
Entering her chamber to bestow on her
A customed visit; find the pillow swelled,
unbruised with any weight, the sheets unruffled,
The curtains neither drawn, nor bed laid down;
Which shows, she slept not in my house tonight .
Should there be any contract betwixt her
And this my groom, to abuse my honest trust;
I should not take it well, but for all this
Yet cannot I be jealous. Robin▪
Is my horse safe, lusty, and in good plight?
What, feeds he well?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes sir, he's broad buttocked and full flanked, he doth not bate an ace of his flesh.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: When was he rid last?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Not sir since you backed him.

lg.l: Sirrah, take heed I find you not a knave,
Have you not lent him to your mistress late?
So late as this last night?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Who I sir, may I die sir, if you find me in a lie sir.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Then I shall find him where I left him last.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: No doubt sir.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Give me the key o'th stable.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: There sir.

lg.l: Sirrah, your mistress was abroad all night,
Nor is she yet come home, if there I find him not,
I shall find thee, what to this present hour
I never did suspect; and I must tell there
Will not be to thy profit.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Well sir, find what you can, him you shall find, and what you find else; it may before that, instead of gramercy horse, you may say gramercy Robin; you will believe there are no witches! had I not been late bridled, I could have said more, but I hope she is tied to the rack that will confess something, and though not so much as I know, yet no more than I dare justify —
Have you found your gelding sir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Yes, I have.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I hope not spurred, nor put into a sweat, you may see by his plump belly and sleek legs he hath not been sore travailed.

lg.l: You're a saucy groom to receive horses
Into my stable, and not ask me leave.
Is't for my profit to buy hay and oats
For every strangers jades?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I hope sir you find none feeding there but your own, if there be any you suspect, they have nothing to champion, but the bridle.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Sirrah, whose jade is that tied to the rack?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: The mare you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Yes, that old mare.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Old do you call her? You shall find the mark still in her mouth, when the bridle is out of it? I can assure you 'tis your own beast.

lg.l: A beast thou art to tell me so, hath the wine
Not yet left working? not the mitre wine?
That made thee to believe witchcraft?
Prithee persuade me,
To be a drunken sot like to thyself;
And not to know mine own.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I'll not persuade you to any thing, you will believe nothing but what you see, I say the beast is your own, and you have most right to keep her, she hath cost you more the currying, than all the combs in your stable are worth. You have paid for her provender this twenty years and upwards, and furnished her with all the 〈◊〉 that she hath worn, of my knowledge, and because she hath been ridden hard the last night, do you renounce her now?

lg.l: Sirrah, I fear some stolen jade of your own
That you would have me keep.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I am sure I found her no jade the last time I rid her, she carried me the best part of a hundred miles in less than a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: The devil she did!

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Yes so I say, either the devil or she did; an't please you 〈◊〉 in and take off her 〈◊〉, and then tell me who hath more right to her, you or I.

lg.l: Well Robert, for this once I'll play the groom,
And do your office for you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I pray do sir, but take heed lest when the bridle is out of her mouth, she put it not into yours; if she do, you are a gone man: if she but say once ▪ horse, horse, see thou be. Be you rid (If you please) for me.

div.stage: Enter Mr. generous and Mrs. generous, he with a bridle.

lg.l: My blood is turned to ice, and my all vitals
Have ceased their working! dull stupidity
Surpriseth me at once, and hath arrested
That vigorous agitation; which till now
Expressed a life within me: I methinks
Am a mere marble statue, and no man;
Unweave my age oh time, to my first thread;
Let me lose fifty years in ignorance spent:
That being made an infant once again,
I may begin to know, what? or where am I
To be thus lost in wonder.

sp.speaker: Mrs. gen.
sp.p: Sir.

lg.l: Amazement still pursues me, how am I changed
Or brought ere I can understand myself,
Into this new world.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You will believe no witches?

lg.l: This makes me believe all, I any thing;
And that myself am nothing: prithee Robin
Lay me to my 〈◊〉 open, what art thou,
Or this new transformed creature?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I am Robin, and this your wife, my Mrs.

lg.l: Tell me the earth
Shall leave it's seat, and mount to kiss the moon;
Or that the moon enamoured of the earth,
Shall leave her sphere, to stoop to us thus low.
What? what's this in my hand, that at an instant
Can from a four legged creature, make a thing
So like a wife?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: A bridle, juggling bridle sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.

lg.l: A bridle, hence enchantment,
a viper were more safe within my hand
Then this charmed engine

sp.stage: Casts it away. Robin takes it up.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Take heed sir what you do, if you cast it hence, and she catch it up, we that are here now, may be rid as far as the Indies within these few hours, mistress down of your mare's bones, or your marrowbones whether you please, and confess yourself to be what you are; and that's in plain English a witch, a grand notorious witch.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: A witch! my wife a witch!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: So it appears by the story.

lg.l: The more I strive to unwind
Myself from this Meander, I the more
Therein am intricated; prithee woman
Art thou a witch?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: It cannot be denied, I am such a cursed creature.

lg.l: Keep aloof, and do not come too near me, oh my trust;
Have I since first I understood myself,
Been of my soul so chary, still to study
What best was for it's health, to renounce all
The works of that black fiend with my best force
And hath that serpent twined me so about,
That I must lie so often and so long
With a devil in my bosom!

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Pardon sir.

lg.l: Pardon! Can such a thing as that be hoped?
Lift up thine eyes (Lost woman) to yon hills;
It must be thence expected: look not down
Unto that horrid dwelling, which thou hast sought
At such dear rate to purchase, prithee tell me,
(For now I can believe) art thou a witch?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I am.

lg.l: With that word I am thunderstruck,
And know not what to answer, yet resolve me
Hast thou made any contract with that fiend
The enemy of mankind?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: O I have.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What? and how far?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I have promised him my soul.

lg.l: Ten thousand times better thy body had
been promised to the stake, I and mine too,
To have suffered with thee in a hedge of flames:
Then such a compact ever had been made. O —

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: What cheese sir, show yourself a man, though she appeared so late a beast; mistress confess all, better here than in a worse place, out with it.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Resolve me, how far doth that contract stretch?

lg.l: What interest in this soul, myself could claim
I freely gave him, but his part that made it
I still reserve, not being mine to give.
Oh cunning devil, foolish woman know
Where he can claim but the least little part,
He will usurp the whole; thou art a lost woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I hope not so.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Why hast thou any hope?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Yes sir I have.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Make it appear to me.

lg.l: I hope I never bargained for that fire,
Further than penitent tears have power to quench.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I would see some of them.

lg.l: You behold them now.
(If you look on me with charitable eyes)
Tinctured in blood, blood issuing from the heart,
Sir I am sorry; when I look towards heaven
I beg a gracious pardon; when on you
Methinks your native goodness should not be
Less pitiful than they: 'gainst both I have erred,
From both I beg atonement.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: May I presume't?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I kneel to both your mercies.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.p: Know'st thou what a witch is?

lg.l: Alas, none better,
Or after mature recollection can be
More sad to think on't.
Tell me, are those tears
As full of true hearted penitence,
As mine of sorrow, to behold what state
what desperate state thou'rt fallen in.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Sir they are.

lg.l: Rise, and as I do, so heaven pardon me;
We all offend, but from such falling off,
Defend us. Well, I do remember wife,
When I first took thee, 'twas for good and bad;
Oh change thy bad to good, that I may keep thee,
As then we passed our faiths, till death us sever.
I will not aggravate thy grief too much,
By needles iteration: Robin hereafter
Forget thou hast a tongue, if the least syllable
Of what hath passed be rumoured, you lose me;
But if I find you faithful, you gain me ever.
A match sir, you shall find me as mute as if I had the
Bridle still in my mouth.
O woman thou hadst need to weep thyself
Into a fountain, such a penitent spring
As may have power to quench invisible flames
In which my eyes shall aid; too little all,
If not too little, all's forgiven, forgotten;
Only thus much remember, thou hadst extermined
Thyself out of the blessed society
Of saints and angels, but on thy repentance
I take thee to my bosom, once again,
My wife, sister, and daughter: saddle my gelding,
Some business that may hold me for two days
Calls me aside.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I shall sir, well now my mistress hath promised to give over her witchery, I hope though I still continue her man, yet she will make me no more her journeyman; to prevent which the first thing I do shall be to burn the bridle, and then away with the witch.

sp.speaker: A●th
sp.p: Sir you have done a right noble courtesy, which deserves a memory, as long as the name of friendship can bear mention.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: What I have done, I ha'done, if it be well, 'tis well, i do not like the bouncing of good offices, if the little care I have taken shall do these poor people good, I have my end in't, and so my reward.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Now gentlemen, you seem very serious.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: 'Tis true we are so, but you are welcome to the knowledge of our affairs.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: How does thine uncle and aunt, Gregory and his sister, the families of Seelyes agree yet, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: That is the business, the silly household is divided now.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: How so I pray?

lg.l: You know, and cannot but with pity know
Their miserable condition, how
The good old couple were abused, and how
The young abused themselves; if we may say
That any of hem are their selves at all
Which sure we cannot, nor approve them fit
To be their own disposers, that would give
The governance of such a house and living
Into their vassals hands, to thrust them out on't
Without or law or order, this considered
This gentleman and myself have taken home
By fair entreaty, the old folks to his house,
The young to mine, until some wholesome order
By the judicious of the commonwealth,
Shall for their persons and estate be taken.
But what becomes of Lawrénce and his Parnell?
The lusty couple, what do they now?

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Alas poor folks, they are as far to seek of how they do, or what they do, or what they should do, as any of the rest, they are all grown idiots, and till some of these damnable jades, with their devilish devices be found out, tod scharme them, no remedy can be found, I mean to lay the country for their hagships, and if i can anticipate the purpose, of their grand Mr. devil to confound 'em before their lease be out, be sure I'll do 't ▪

sp.speaker: Cry.
sp.p: A Skimington, a Skimmington, a Skimington.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: What's the matter now, is hell broke loose?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Tom Shakstone, how now, canst tell the news?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: The news, ye hear it up i'th air, do you not?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: A Skimington, a Skimington, a Skimington.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Hark ye, do you not hear it? there's a Skimington, towards gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Ware wedlock ho.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: At whose suit I prithee is don Skimington come to town.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: I'll tell you gentlemen, since you have taken home old silly and his wife to your house, and you their son and daughter to yours, the housekeepers Lawrence, and his late bride Parnell are fallen out by themselves.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: How prithee?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: The quarrel began they say upon the wedding night, and in the bride bed.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: For want of bedstaves?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: No but a better implement it seems the bridegroom was unprovided of, a homely tale to tell.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Now out upon her she has a greedy worm in her, I have heard the fellow complained on, for an over mickle man among the maids.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Is his haste to go to bed at afternoon come to this now?

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Witchery, witchery, more witchery still flat and plain witchery. Now do I think upon the codpiece point the young jade gave him at the wedding: she is a witch, and that was a charm, if there be any in the world.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A ligatory point.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Alas poor Lawrence.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: He's coming to make his moan to you about it, and she too, since you have taken their masters and mistresses to your care, you must do them right too.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Marry but I'll not undertake her at these years, if lusty Lawrence cannot do't.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: But has she beaten him?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Grievously broke his head in I know not how many places: of which the hoydens have taken notice, and will have a Skimmington on horseback presently. Look ye, here comes both plaintiff and defendant.

sp.speaker: Dough
sp.p: How now Lawrence, what has thy wedlock brought thee already to thy nightcap?

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Yie gadwat sir, I beware wadded but awe to seun.
Han ye reeson to complain or ay trow ye gaffer Downought? Wa warth the day that ever I wadded a Downought.

sp.speaker: Ar. Ban. Sha.
sp.p: Nay hold parnel hold.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: We have heard enough of your valour already, wec know you have beaten him, let that suffice.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Ware ever poor maiden betrayed as ay beware unto a swag-bellied carl that cannot awe waw that cannot.

sp.speaker: ●ou
sp.p: What says she?

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: I know not, she caterwauls I think. Parnel be patient good Parnell, and a little modest too, 'tis not amiss, we know not the relish of every ear that hears us, let's talk within ourselves. What's the defect? What's the impediment? Lawrence has had a lusty name among the bachelors.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What he wore when he beware a bachelor, I know better than the best maid ith' tawn. I wad I had not.

sp.speaker: Ar. Ba. Sha.
sp.p: Peace Parnell.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: 'twere that, that cozened me, he has not now as he had then?

sp.speaker: Ar. Ba. Sha.
sp.p: Peace good Parnell.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: For then he could, but now he cannot, he cannot.

sp.speaker: Ar. Ba. Sha
sp.p: Fie parnel fie.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I say again and again, he cannot, he cannot.

sp.speaker: Ar. ba Sha.
sp.p: Alas poor Parnel.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I am not a bit the better for him sin weigh ware wad. cries

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: Here's good stuff for a jury of women to pass upon.

lg.l: But parnel, why have you beaten him so grievously?
What would you have him do in this case?

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: He's out of a doing case it seems.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Marry sir, and beat him will I into his grave, or back to the priest, and be unwadded ago, for I wonot be band to lig with him and live with him the laife of an honest woman for awe the layves good i' Loncoshire.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: An honest woman: that's a good mind parnel what say you to this Lawrence?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Keep her of o'me, and I shan gloxx yeou, and she be by I am nobody : but keep her off and search me, let me be searched as never witch was searched, and find only thing more or lass upon me than a sufficient mon should have, and let me be hon● by't.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Do you hear this Parnell?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ah leear, leear, mi tack the leear, troist ye and hung ye.

lg.l: Alas it is too plain, the poor fellow is bewitched.
Here's a plain maleficium versus hanc now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: And so is she bewitched too into this immodesty.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.p: She would never talk so else

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: I prayn you give me the lere o'that Latin sir.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: The meaning is, you must get half a dozen bastards within this twelvemonth, and that will mend your next marriage.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: And I thought it would my parnel, love me I'd be sure on't, and gang about it now right.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: You're soon provided it seems for such a journey.

sp.speaker: Dou
sp.p: Best tarry till thy head be whole Lawrence.

lg.l: Nay, nay, ay's white casten away ent I be unwadded again▪
And then ine undertake to find 3 better husbands in a bean cod.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Heark gentlemen, the show is coming.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: What shall we stay and see't.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.p: O by all means gent.

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.p: 'Tis best to have these away first.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Nay marry shan eou not sir, I hear ye well enough, and I con the meaning o'the show well enough, and I stay not the show and see not the show, and ●a'one i'the show, let me be honked up for a show I'll beware them to mell or ma with a woman that melts or maes with a testril a longie, a dow little lozel that cannot, and if I skim not their skimingtons cockskeam for't, ma that warplin boggle me a week lonker, and that's a curse eno' for any wife I trow.
from the board, and yet for ought I can see I am never a whit the nearer what not one kiss at parting 〈◊〉?

lg.l: Well cousin this is all you have to do:
Retire the gallants to some private room,
Where call for wine, and junkets what you please,
Then thou shalt need to do no other thing
Than what this note directs thee, observe that
An trouble me no farther.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Very good, I like this beginning well: for where they slighted me before, they shall find me a man of note.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Of this the meaning

lg.l: Marry lass
To bring a new conceit to pass.
Thy spirit must borrow more,
To fill the number three or four;
Whom we will use to no great harm,
Only assist me with thy charm.
This night we'll celebrate to 〈◊〉:
'Tis all for mirth, we mean no hurt.
My spirit and myself command;
Mamillion, and the rest at hand, shall all assist.
Withdraw then, quick,
Now gallants, there's for you a 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Here's a more private room gentlemen, free from the noise of the hall. Here we may talk, and throw the chamber out of the casements. Some wine and a short banquet.

div.stage: Enter with a boquet, wine, and two t●perss.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: So now leave us.

lg.l: We are much bound to you master Whetstone.
For this great entertainment: I see you command
The house in the absence of your uncle.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Yes, I thank my aunt; for though I be but a daily guest yet I can be welcome to her at midnight.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: How shall we pass the time?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: In some discourse.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: But no such discourse as we had last, 〈◊〉 each you.

lg.l: Now master Whetstone you reflect on me.
'Tis true, at our last meeting some few words
Then 〈◊〉 my lips, which I could wish forgotten:
I think I called you bastard.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I think so too; but what's that amongst friends, for I would fain know which amongst you all knows his own father.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: You are merry with your friends, good master By-blow, and we are guests here in your uncle's house, and therefore privileged.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: I presume you had no more privilege in your getting than 〈◊〉. But tell me gentlemen, is there any man here amongst you, that hath a mind to see his father?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Why, who shall show him?

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: That's all one; if any man here desire it, let him but speak the word, and 'tis sufficient.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Why, I would see my father.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gener.
sp.p: Strike.

div.stage: Enter a pedant dancing to the 〈◊〉; the strain don, he points at Bantam, and looks full in his face.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Do you know him that looks so full in your face;

lg.l: Yes well, a pedant in my father's house.
Who being young, taught me my a, b, c.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: In his house, that goes for your father you would say: for know one morning, 〈◊〉 your mother's husband rid early to have a nisi prius tried at Lancaster assizeses, he crept into his warm place, lay close by her side, and then were you got. Then come, your heels and tail 〈◊〉, and kneel 〈◊〉 your own dear father.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: I am abused.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Why laugh you gentlemen? It may be more men's cases than his or mine. Bant. To be thus 〈◊〉.

lg.l: Come, take it as a jest
For presume 'twas meant no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Would either of you two now see his father in earnest

sp.speaker: Shak
sp.p: Yes, canst thou show me mine?

div.stage: Enter a nimble tailor dancing, using the same posture to Shakstone.

sp.speaker: Whet
sp.p: He looks on you speak, do you know him?

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: Yes, he was my mother's tailor, I remember him ever since I was a child.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Who when he came to take measure of her upper parts had more mind to the lower, whilst the good man was in the fields hunting, he was at home 〈◊〉.

lg.l: Then, since no better comfort 〈◊〉 be had,
Come down, come down, ask blessing of your dad.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: This cannot be endured.

lg.l: It is plain witchcraft.
Nay since we all are bid unto one feast,
Let's fare alike, come show me mine too.

sp.speaker: Mrs Gener.
sp.p: Strike.

div.stage: Enter Robin with a switch and a Currycombe, he points at Arthur.

sp.speaker: Whet
sp.p: He points at you.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: You know him.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Yes, robin 〈◊〉 groom belonging to this house.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: And never served your father?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: In's youth I think he did.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p:
Who when your supposed father had business at the lord presidents court in York, stood for his attorney at home, and so it seems you were got by deputy: what all a mort? if
you will have but a little patience, stay and you shall see mine too:

lg.l: And know I show you him the rather,
To find who hath the best man to his father.

div.stage: 〈◊〉. Enter a gallant, 〈◊〉 before to him.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Now gentlemen make me your precedent, learn your duties, and 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 I do — a blessing dad.

lg.l: Come, come, let's home, we'll find 〈◊〉 other time,
When to dispute of these things —

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: : nay gent. no 〈◊〉 in 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 begun in 〈◊〉, let's not end in 〈◊〉; you see 〈◊〉 are more by-blows than bear the 〈◊〉; it is grown a great kindred in the kingdom. Come, come, all friends; let's into the cellar and conclude our revels in a lusty health.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: I fain would strike, but cannot.
Some strange fate holds me.

lg.l: Here then all anger end,
Let none be mad at what they cannot mend.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Now say what's next?

lg.l: I'th' mill there lies
A soldier yet with unscratched eyes,
Summon the sisterhood together
For we with all our spirits will thither;
And such a caterwauling keepe,
That 〈◊〉 in vain shall think to sleep.
Call Meg, and doll, 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 jug,
Let none appear without her pug.
We'll try our utmost art and skill.
To fright the stout knave in the 〈◊〉.

div.head: Actus, v. Scaena, i.
div.stage: Enter Doughty, miller, boy in a c●p ▪

sp.speaker: Doughty ▪
sp.p: Thou art a brave boy, the honour of thy country ; thy statue shall be set up in brass upon the market cross in Lancaster, I bless the time that I answered at the 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 thee: 'zookes did I ever think that a godson of mine should have fought hand to fist with the devil!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: He was ever an unhappy boy sir, and like enough to grow acquainted with him; and friends may fall out sometimes.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Thou art a dogged sire, and doest not know the virtue of my godson, my son now; he shall be thy son no longer: he and I will worry all the witches in Lancashire.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: You were best take heed though.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: I care not, though we leave not above three untainted women in the parish, we'll do it.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Do what you please sir, there's the boy stout enough to justify any thing he has said. Now 'tis out, he should be my son still by that: though he was at death's 〈◊〉 before he would reveal any thing, 〈◊〉 damnable jades had so threatened him, and as soon as ever he had told he mended.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: 'Tis well he did so, we will so swing them in twopenny halter's boy.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: For my part I have no reason to hinder any thing that may root them all out; I have tasted enough of their mischief, witness my usage i' th' mill, which could be nothing but their roguery. One night in my sleep they set me a stride stark naked a top of my mill, a bitter cold night too; 'twas day light before I woke , and I durst never speak of it to this hour, because I thought it impossible to be believed.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Villainous hags

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: And all last summer, my wife could not make a bit of butter.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: It would not come, 〈◊〉 it?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: No sir, we could not make it come, though she and I both together, churned almost our 〈◊〉 out, and nothing would come, but all ran into thin waterish gear: the pigs would not drink 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Is't possible ▪

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: None but one, and he ran out of his wits upon't, till we bound his head, and laid him asleep , but he has had a wry mouth ever since.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: That the devil should put in their hearts to delight in such villainies! I have sought 〈◊〉 these two days, and her of a 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, though none mortal, but could not find whom to mistrust for a witch till now this boy, this happy boy informs me.

And they should ne'er have been sought for me if their affrightments and devilish devices, had not brought my boy into such a sickness; whereupon indeed I thought good to acquaint your worship, and bring the boy unto you being his godfather, and as you now stick not to say his father.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: After you I thank yo● gossip. But my boy thou hast satisfied me in their names, and thy knowledge of the women, their turning into shapes, their dog-trickes, and their horse tricks, and their great feast in the barn (A pox take them with my sirloin, I say still.) But a little more of thy combat with the devil, I prithee; he came to thee like a boy thou sayest, about thine own bigness?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes sir, and he asked me where I dwelled, and what my name was.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Ah rogue!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But it was in a quarrelsome way; whereupon I was as stout, and asked him who made him an examiner?

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Ah good boy.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: In that he was my son.

lg.l: He told me he would know or beat it out of me,
And I told him he should not, and bid him do his worst;
And to't we went.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: In that he was my son again, ha boy; I see him at it now.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: We fought a quarter of an hour, till his sharp nails made my ears bleed.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: O the grand devil pare 'em.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I wondered to find him so strong in my hands, seeming but of mine own age and bigness, till I looking down, perceived he had clubbed cloven feet like ox feet; but his face was as young as mine.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: A pox, but by his feet, he may be the club-footed horse-coursers father, for all his young looks.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But I was afraid of his feet, and ran from him towards a light that I saw, and when I came to it, it was one of the witches in white upon a bridge, that scared me back again, and then met me the boy again, and he struck me and laid me for dead.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Till I wondering at his stay, went out and found him in the trance; since which time, he has been haunted and frighted with goblins, 40. times, and never durst tell any thing (As I said) because the hags had so threatened him till in his sickness he revealed it to his mother.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: And she told nobody but folks on't. Well gossip Gretty, as thou art a miller, and a close thief, now let us keep it as close as we may till we take 'em, and see them handsomely hanged of the way: ha my little cuss-devil, thou art a made man. Come, away with me.

lg.l: These two nights I have slept well and heard no noise
Of cats, or rats; most sure the fellow dreamt,
And scratched himself in is sleep. I have travelled deserts,
Beheld wolves, bears, and lions: indeed what not?
Of horrid shape; and shall I be afraid
Of cats in mine own country? I can never
Grow so mouse-hearted. It is now a calm
And no wind stirring, I can bear no sail;
than best lie down to sleep. Nay rest by me
Good morglay, my comrade and bedfellow
That never failed me yet; I know thou didst not.
If I be waked, see thou be stirring too;
Then come a Gib as big as Ascapart
We'll make him play at leapfrog. A brave soldier's lodging,
The floor my bed, a millstone for my pillow,
The sails for curtains. So good night.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. generous, Mall, all the witches and their spirits (At several doors.)

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Is Nab come?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Where's Jug?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: But where's Peg?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Entered the mill already.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Is he fast?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As senseless as a dormouse.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Then to work, to work my pretty Lapland's
Do that within, without we'll keep the watch.

div.stage: The witches retired: the spirits come about him with a dreadful noise: he starts.

lg.l: Am I in hell, then have amongst you devils;
This side, and that side, what behind, before?
I'll keep my face unscratched despite you all:
What, do you pinch in private, claws I feel
But can see nothing, nothing pinch me thus?
Have at you then, I and have at you still;
And still have at you.
lg.stage: Beates them off, follows them in, and enters again.
lg.l: One of them I have paid
In leaping out oth' hole a foot or ear
Or something I have light on. What all gone?
All quiet? not a cat that's heard to mew?
Nay then I'll try to take another nap,
though I sleep with mine eyes open.
Robin, the last night that I lodged at home
My wife (If thou remember'st) lay abroad,
But no words of that.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You have taught me silence.

lg.l: I rose thus early much before my hour,
To take her in her bed ▪ 'tis yet not five:
The sun scarce up. Those horses take and lead 'em
Into the stable, see them rubbed and dressed,
We have rid hard. Now in the interim I
Will step and see how my new miller fares,
Or whether he slept better in his charge,
Than those which did precede him.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir I shall.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: But one thing more —

lg.l: Now from the last night's witchcraft we are freed,
And I that had not power to clear myself
From base aspersion, am at liberty
For vowed revenge: I cannot be at peace
(The night-spell being took of) till I have met
With noble Mr. generous: in whose search
The best part of this morning I have spent,
His wife now I suspect.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: By your leave sir.

lg.l: O you're well met, pray tell me how long is't
Since you were first my father?

sp.speaker: Rob
sp.p: Be patient I beseech you, what do you mean sir?

lg.l: But that I honour
Thy master, to whose goodness I am bound,
And still must remain thankful, I should prove
Worse than a murderer, a mere parricide
by killing thee my father.
I your father? he was a man I always loved
And honoured. He bred me.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: And you begotten me? o you used me finely last night?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Pray what's the matter sir?

lg.l: My worthy friend, but that I honour you
As one to whom I am so much obliged,
This villain could not stir a foot from hence
Till perished by my sword.
How hath he wronged you?
Be of a milder temper I entreat,
Relate what and when done?
You may command me,
If ask me what wrongs, know this groom pretends
He hath strumpeted my mother, if when, blazed
Last night at midnight. If you ask me further
Where, in your own house; when he pointed to me
As had I been his bastard.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I do this? I am a horse again if I got you, master, why master.

lg.l: I know you Mr. Arthur, for a gentleman
Of fair endowments, a most solid brain,
And settled understanding. Why this fellow
These two days was scarce sundered from my side,
And for the last night I am most assured
He slept within my chamber, 12. miles off,
We have never parted since.
You tell me wonders.
Since all your words to me are oracles,
And such as I most constantly believe.
But sir, shall I be bold and plain withal,
I am suspicious all's not well at home;
I dare proceed no farther without leave,
Yet there is something lodged within my breast
Which I am loath to utter.
Keep it there,
I pray do a season (Oh my fears)
In my uncle's absence who but I should comfort my aunt,
Am I not of the blood, am not I next of kin?
Why aunt?

sp.speaker: Mrs. gen
sp.p: Good nephew leave me.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: The devil shall leave you ere I'll forsake you, aunt, you know, sic is so, and being so sick do you think I'll leave you, what know I but this bed may prove your deathbed, and and then I hope you will remember me, that is, remember me in your will.
Who's that knocks with such authority. Ten to one my uncle's come to town.

sp.speaker: Mrs. gen.
sp.p: If it be so, excuse my weakness to him, say I can speak with none.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I will, and scape him if I can; by this accident all must come out, and here's no stay for me
Again, stay you here with your aunt, and I'll go let in your uncle.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Do good mal, and how, and how sweet aunt?

div.stage: Enter Mr. Gener. Mal, Arthur, soldier, and Robin.

lg.l: You're well met here, I am told you oft frequent
This house as my wife's choice companion,
Yet have I seldom seen you.
Pray, by your leave sir,
Your wife is taken with a sudden qualm
She hath sent me for a doctor.
But that labour I'll save you, soldier take her to your charge.
And now where's this sick woman.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: O uncle you come in good time, my aunt is so suddenly taken as if she were ready to give up the spirit.

lg.l: 'Tis almost time she did, speak how is't wife
My nephew tells me you were taken last night
With a shrewd sickness, which this maid confirms.
Yes sir, but now desire no company.
Noise troubles me, and I would gladly sleep.
In company there's comfort, prithee wife
Lend me thy hand, and let me feel thy pulse,
Perhaps some fever, by their beating I
may guess at thy disease.

sp.speaker: Mrs. gen.
sp.p: My hand, 'tis there.

lg.l: A dangerous sickness, and I fear t death,
'Tis odds you will not scape it. Take that back
And let me prove the tother, if perhaps
I there can find more comfort.

sp.speaker: Mrs. gen.
sp.p: I pray excuse me.

lg.l: I must not be denied,
Sick folks are peevish, and must be o'erruled, and so shall you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. gen.
sp.p: Alas I have not strength to lift it up.

lg.l: If not thy hand wife, show me but thy wrist,
And see how this will match it, here's a testate
That cannot be outfaced.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gener.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Hath my aunt been playing at handy dandy, nay then if the game go this way I fear she'll have the worst hand on't.

lg.l: 'Tis now apparent
How all the last night's business came about,
In this my late suspicion, is confirmed.
My heart hath bled more for thy cursed relapse
Than drops hath issued from thy wounded arm.
But wherefore should I preach to one past hope?
Or where the devil himself claims right in all,
Seek the least part or interest? Leave your bed,
Up, make you ready; I must deliver you
Into the hand of justice. O dear friend
It is in vain to guess at this my grief
'Tis so inundant. Soldier take away that young
But old in mischief.
And being of these apostates rid so well,
I'll see my house no more be made a hell.
Away with them.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.p: I'll out o'the country, and as soon live in Lapland as Lancashire hereafter.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: What for a false illusive apparition? I hope the devil is not able to persuade thee thou art a bastard.

sp.speaker: Bant
sp.p: No, but I am afflicted to think that the devil should have power to put such a trick upon us, to countenance a rascal, that is one.

sp.speaker: Shak
sp.p: I hope Arthur has taken a course with his uncle about him by this time, who would have thought such a fool as he could have been a witch?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Why do you think there's any wise folks of the quality; can any but fools be drawn into a covenant with the greatest enemy of mankind? yet i cannot think that whetstone is the witch? The young quean that was at the wedding was i'th house ye know.

div.stage: Enter Lawrence and Parnell, in their first habits.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: See Lawrence and Parnell civilly accorded again it seems, and accoutred as they were wont to be when they had their wits.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Blessed be the hour I say may honey, may sweet pall, that ay's becomed thaine ago, and thou's becomed main ago, and may this ea kiss ma us tway become both eane for ever and a day.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Yie marry Lall, and thus shadden it be, there is naught gotten by fawing out, we must favu in or we get naught.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: The world's well mended here; we cannot but rejoice to see this, Lawrence.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: And you been welcome to it gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: And we been glad we han it for you.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: And I protest I am glad to see it.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: And thus shan ye see't till our deeing hour.
Ween eon leove now for a laife time, the dewle shouldn't ha' the poor to put us to pieces ago.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Why now all's right and straight and as it should be.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p:
Yie marry that is it, the good hour be blessed for it, that put the wit into may head, to have a mistrust of that pestilent codpiece-point, that the witched worch mal Spencer go
me, ah woe worth her, that were it that made awe so naught.

sp.speaker: Bant. and Shak.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Yie marry it were an enchantment, and about an hour since it come until our hearts to do, what ye think, and we did it.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: What Parnell?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Marry we take the point, and we casten the point into the fire, and the point spittered and spattered in the fire, like an it were (Love bless us) a laive thing in the fair; and it hopped and skippet, and riggle, and frisket in the fair, and crept about laike a worm in the fair, that it were work enough for us both with all the chimney tools to keep it into the fair, and it stinket in the fair, worsen than only brimstone in the fair.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: This is wonderful as all the rest.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: It would ha' scared only that hadden their wits till a seen't, and we werne mad eoht it were deone.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: And this were not above an hour since, and you cannot devise how we han loved t'one tother by now, ye would e'en bliss your self to see't.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: Yie an han pit on our working gear, to swink and serve our master and mistress like until painful servants ago, as we shudden.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: 'Tis wondrous well.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: And are they well again?

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Yie and weel's laike heane bliss them, they are awas we'll becomed as none ill had ever been aneast'hem; lo ye, lo ye, as they come.

div.stage: Enter Seely, Joane, Gregory and Win.

lg.l: Sir, if a contrite heart struck through with sense
Of it's sharp errors, bleeding with remorse
The black polluted stain it had conceived
Of foul unnatural disobedience
May yet by your fair mercy find remission;
You shall upraise a son out o'the gulf
Of horror and despair, unto a bliss
That shall for ever crown your goodness, and
instructive in my after life to serve you,
In all the duties that be fit a son.
Enough, enough, good boy, 'tis most apparent
We all have had our errors, and as plainly
It now appears, our judgements, yea our reason
Was poisoned by some violent infection,
Quite contrary to nature.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: This sounds well.

lg.l: I fear it was by witchcraft: for I now
(Blessed be the power that wrought the happy means
Of my delivery) remember that
Some 3. months since I crossed a way ward woman
(One that I now suspect) for bearing with
A most unseemly disobedience,
In an untoward ill-bred son of hers,
When with an ill look and an hollow voice
She muttered out these words. Perhaps erelong
Thyself shalt be obedient to thy son.
She has played her prank it seems.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Sir I have heard, that witches apprehended under hands of lawful authority, do lose their power; and all their spells are instantly dissolved.

lg.l: If it be so, then at this happy hour,
The witch is ta'en that over us had power.

sp.speaker: Joane.
sp.p: Enough child, thou art mine and all is well.

lg.l: Long may you live the wellspring of my bliss,
And may my duty and my fruitful prayers,
Draw a perpetual stream of blessings from you.
Gentlemen welcome to my best friends house,
You know the unhappy cause that drew me hither.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: And cannot but rejoice to see the remedy so near at hand.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Come gossip, come boy — gentlemen you are come to the bravest discovery — Mr. silly and the rest, how is't with you? you look reasonable well methinks .

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: Sir, we do find that we have reason enough to thank you for your neighbourly and pious care of us.

sp.speaker: Doughty.
sp.p: Is all so well with you already? go to, will you know a reason for't gentlemen: I have caught a whole kennel of witches. It seems their witch is one of 'em, and so they are discharmed, they are all in officers hands, and they will touch here with two or three of them for a little private parley, before they go to the justices. Master generous is coming hither too, with a supply that you dream not of, and your nephew Arthur.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: You are beholden sir to master generous in behalf of your nephew for saving his land from forfeiture in time of your distraction.

sp.speaker: Seely.
sp.p: I will acknowledge it most thankfully.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.p: See he comes.

div.stage: Enter Mr. generous, Mrs. generous, Arthur, Wherstone, Mal, soldier, and Robin.

lg.l: O Mr. generous, the noble favour you have showed
My nephew for ever binds me to you.
I pitied then your misery, and now
Have nothing left but to bewail mine own
In this unhappy woman.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: Good mistress generous —

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Make a full stop there sir, sides, sides, make sides, you know her not as I do, stand aloof there mistress with your darling witch, your nephew too if you please, because though he be no witch, he is a well-willer to the infernal science.

lg.l: I utterly discard him in her blood
And all the good that I intended him
I will confer upon this virtuous gentleman.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Well sir, though you be no uncle, yet mine aunt's mine aunt, and shall be to her dying day.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: And that will be about a day after next sizes I take it,

div.p:
O here comes more o'your naunts, naunt Dickenson and naunt
Hargrave, ods fish and your granny Johnson too; we want but a good fire to entertain 'em.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: See how they lay their heads together?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: No succour.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: No relief.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No comfort!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Mawsy, my Mawsy, gentle Mawsy come,

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Come my sweet puckling.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: My Mamilion.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What do they say?

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: They call their spirits I think.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Now a shame take you for a farthel of fools, have you known so many of the devil's tricks, and can be ignorant of that common feat of the old juggler; that is, to leave you all to the law, when you are once seized on by the talons of authority? I'll undertake this little demigorgon constable with these commonwealth characters upon his staff here, is able inspite of all your bugs-words, to stave off the grand devil for doing any of you good till you come to his kingdom to him, and there take what you can find.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: But gentlemen, shall we try if we can by examination get from them something that may abbreviate the cause unto the wiser in commission for the peace before we carry them before 'em.

sp.speaker: Gen. and Seel.
sp.p: Let it be so.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Well say, stand out boy, stand out miller, stand out Robin, stand out soldier, and lay your accusation upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Speak boy do you know these creatures, women I dare not call 'em?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes sir, and saw them all in the barn together, and many more at their feast and witchery.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And so did I, by a devilish token, I was rid thither, though I rid home again as fast without switch or spur.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I was ill handled by them in the mill.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: And I sliced off a cat's foot there, that is since a hand, whoever wants it.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: How I and all my family have suffered you all know.

sp.speaker: Lawr.
sp.p: And how I were bewitched my pall. here knows.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p:
Yie Lall, and the witch I knaw, an I prayen ye go
me but leave to scrat her well-favouredly.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: Hold Parnell.

sp.speaker: Parn.
sp.p: Ye can blame no honest woman, I trow, to scrat for the thing she loves.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Do you laugh gentlewoman? what say you to all these matters?

lg.l: I will say nothing, but what you know you know,
And as the law shall find me let it take me.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And so say I.

sp.speaker: Mawd.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And I, other confession you get none from us.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What say you granny?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Mamilion, ho Mamilion, Mamilion.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Who's that you call?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: My friend, my sweetheart, my Mamilion.

sp.speaker: Witches.
sp.p: You are not mad?

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Ah ha, that's her devil, her incubus I warrant; take her off from the rest they'll hurt her. Come hither poor old woman. I'll dandle a witch a little, thou wilt speak, and tell the truth, and shalt have favour doubt not. Say art not thou a witch?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: 'Tis folly to dissemble yeah sir, I am one.

lg.l: And that Mamilion which thou callest upon
Is thy familiar devil is't not? Nay prithee speak.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: That's a good woman, how long hast had's acquaintance, ha?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: A matter of six years sir.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: A pretty matter. What was he like a man?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes when I pleased.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: And then he lay with thee, did he not sometimes?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: 'Tis folly to dissemble; twice a week he never failed me.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Humh — and how? and how a little? was he a good bedfellow?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: 'Tis folly to speak worse of him than he is.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: I trust me is't. Give the devil his due.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: He pleased me well sir, like a proper man.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: There was sweet coupling.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Only his flesh felt cold.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: He wanted his great fires about him that he has at home.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: Peace, and did he wear good clothes?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Gentleman like, but black black points and all.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Ay, very like his points were black enough. But come we'll trifle wi'ye no longer. Now shall you all to the justices, and let them take order with you till the sizes, and then let law take his course, and uivat rex. Mr. generous I am sorry for your cause of sorrow, we shall not have your company?

lg.l: No sir, my prayers for her soul's recovery.
Shall not be wanting to her, but mine eyes
Must never see her more.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Mal, adieu sweet mal, ride your next journey with the company you have there.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well rogue I may live to ride in a coach before I come to the gallows yet.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And Mrs. the horse that stays for you rides better with a halter than your gingling bridle.

sp.speaker: Dought.
sp.p: Mr. Seely I rejoice for your family's atonement.

sp.speaker: Seel.
sp.p: And I praise heaven for you that were the means to it.

sp.speaker: Dough.
sp.p: On afore drovers with your untoward cattle.

lg.l: Why do not you follow Mr. byblow. I thank your
Aunt for the trick she would have fathered us withal.

sp.speaker: Whet.
sp.p: Well sir, mine aunt's mine aunt, and for that trick I will not leave her till I see her do a worse.

sp.speaker: Bant.
sp.p: You're a kind kinsman.

lg.l: 1 come Mawsy, come puckling,
And come my sweet suckling,
My pretty Mamillion, my joy,
Fall each to his duggy,
While kindly we buggy,
As tender as nurse over boy.
Then suck our bloods freely, and with it be jolly,
While merrily we sing, heigh trolly-lolly .
2 we'll dandle and clip ye,
We'll stroke ye, and leap ye,
And all that we have is your due;
The feats you do for us,
And those which you store us
Withal, ties us only to you.
Then suck our bloods freely, and with it be jolly,
While merrily we sing, heigh trolly-lolly .
Now while the witches must expect their due
By lawful justice, we appeal to you
For favourable censure; what their crime
May bring upon 'em, ripeness yet of time
Has not revealed. Perhaps great mercy may
After just condemnation give them day
Of longer life. We represent as much
As they have done, before law's hand did touch
Upon their guilt; but dare not hold it fit,
That we for justices and judges sit.
And personate their grave wisdoms on the stage
Whom we are bound to honour; no, the age
Allows it not. Therefore unto the laws
We can but bring the witches and their cause,
And there we leave 'em, as their devils did,
Should we go further with 'em? Wit forbid;
What of their story, further shall ensue,
We must refer to time, ourselves to you.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
